CAR Process Phases and Functions

Cash Allocation and Rebalancing

Key concepts of Cash Allocation and Rebalancing
  • There are three standard processes: Cash Allocation and Rebalancing, commonly referred to as CAR; and Start of Day. The Start of Day process utilises the same process flow and template as CAR.
  • Cash Allocation processes are organised into standard processing phases which are executed in a pre-defined sequence.
  • Cash Allocation processes are driven through the configuration of the processing template and the setting of attributes associated to an entity.
  • A set of worktables are used to load data used by the CAR process, store static data such as tolerances and target weights, and to hold results of processing for other downstream calculations or reporting.
  • pControl captures and processes orders and transactions for an entity, which updates the asset balances, registry balances and internal account balances. The CAR process uses these up to date balances to calculate an entity's liquidity position and actual investment position of its underlying assets for a given day or point in time.
  • The key balances that are maintained and used by the Cash Allocation process are investment holdings and internal account balances.
  • The output of the CAR process is a proposed order which can be used as the basis of a market order.
  • The Cash Allocation process understands multi-level interfund investment structures. The CAR process for an individual fund, the process will 'wait' until all investors (originator entities) have been processed before commencing so that all cashflows into the entity have been calculated.
  • The Cash Allocation process calculates the liquidity position (available cash, inclusive of payables/receivables) and current allocation weights to underlying assets for the entity.
  • A target investment structure is defined in pControl (using Allocation Parameters, known as ALPs) and used to calculate a set of proposed orders for an entity. The allocation parameters maintain the target weights, tolerances and bounds of underlying assets for a given entity. The CAR process also supports notional and model portfolios, which minimise the overhead associated with the maintenance of allocation parameters.
  • CAR supports a number of different methodologies for calculating proposed orders. CAR methodologies can be defined on an entity by entity basis.
  • Balancing / Default options are used to reduce the number of transactions that are sent to the market within an investment structure and also to keep a set of investment (balancing) options' actual allocations in line with their targets.
  • Additional processes that support Cash Allocation include loading allocation parameters, loading classification parameters, loading look-through data, revaluation of exposure, and creating registry orders.

Portfolio Management

The Portfolio Management dashboard is complementary to the Cash Allocation and Rebalancing processes. The PM dashboard supports advanced features such as classification structures and compliance/exposure monitoring. CAR is run to establish start of day balances or undertake cash allocation/rebalancing. The Proposed Transactions generated by the CAR process are displayed in the Portfolio Management dashboard and workflow is managed via the dashboard. These proposed orders generated have 'real time' impact on exposure where classification structures exist on an entity.

Methodologies Introduction

Cash Allocation methodologies supported in pControl include:

  • Straight Percentage
  • Zero Cash To Allocate
  • Towards Target
  • Box Management

Rebalancing methodologies supported by pControl include:

  • Rebalance to Target
  • Partial Rebalance to Percent Target

The methodology to be used for Cash Allocation and Rebalancing processes is specified through the ‘Allocation methodology’ attribute on the fund. The Cash Allocation attribute is shown below. For rebalancing, navigate to the Rebalancing process in the left hand column and select the Calculations phase.

 

 Projection Processes
Cash Projection and Rebalancing Projection

 

Business Description

Cash Projection and Rebalancing Projection provide an accurate view of cash and rebalancing processing, at both current and future dates, taking into account all information currently known. These projections can be calculated for the purposes of:

  • Alerting Portfolio Managers to large cashflows that will be moving in/out of their respective portfolios at a future date
  • Performing analysis on projected cashflows based on alternate sets of allocation parameters (target weights).

Processing Detail

Cash Allocation and Rebalancing Projection processes are run on an ad-hoc basis. Future dated cashflows are projected (processed) based on the effective date of the record(s) in the U308: CashProjection Import worktable. Where the projected process is Cash Allocation, the calculation projects ALRs based on those U308 records, therefore does not load liquidity balances.

Rebalancing projections are used to project a rebalance required at a future date. Future dated rebalancing is effective as of the processing date selected.

Cash and Rebalancing projections do not impact actual investment balances (and actual orders are not created).

Proposed Orders can be modified and saved with the last set of approved cashflows used to drive:

  • the Next Day Cash or Rebalance projection; and
  • actual cash allocation processing when those order proposals are no longer future dated.

The sum of the capital flows and any projected cashflows will be added to any existing liquidity balances to form the available liquidity balance for Projected Orders processing.

Cash Projection

The projected proposed orders are calculated based on the selected allocation methodology i.e. Straight Percentage, Towards Target, and designated ALP set. The allocation parameters applied to the projection are as of the effective date of the future dated cash flow.

For example, Fund A has two sets of allocation parameters defined, one set with effective date 1 January 2020 and the second set with effective date 1 July 2020. If Fund A has a projected cash flow with an effective date of 15 July 2020 loaded into the U308: Cash Projection Import worktable, the fund will use the allocation parameters with effective date 1 July 2020.

The [EX040] - Export Projected Proposed Orders function is required to be selected in order for the proposed orders to be written to the U581: Projected Proposed Orders Export worktable, upon completion of the process.

 

 Rebalancing Projection

The projected proposed orders are calculated based on the selected allocation methodology i.e. Rebalance to Target and Partial Rebalance to Target, and the designated ALP set. If the allocation parameters, as of the effective date of the projected rebalance, are different from the current allocation parameters, then the projected proposed orders will be calculated for a rebalance, even if the positions are within tolerances. If the allocation parameters as of the effective date of the projected rebalance are the same as the current allocation parameters, then the projected rebalance will calculate proposed orders based upon the portfolio being inside/outside tolerances.

The [EX040] - Export Projected Proposed Orders function is required to be selected in order for the proposed orders to be written to the U581: Projected Proposed Orders Export worktable, upon completion of the process.

 

Entity Data Attributes Used

The following functions are found on the CA Projection tab or the RBL Projection tab.

  • Suppress Order Creation
    • Selecting Suppress Order Creation on the relevant CAR entities prevents actual orders from being created, when they are approved.
     

Interdependencies
  • [REG030] - Create Registry Orders must be set to false on the process template. This is to ensure the records from the U110 import worktable are not loaded and processed as part of the projection process.
Prerequisite Functions

Cash Projection

  • Allocation Parameters
  • U308 Cash Projection records
  • [LD180] - Load Projected Cash Flows set to true.
  • U110: Cashflows and Orders

Rebalancing Projection

  • Allocation Parameters
Input

Cash Projection

  • U308: Cash Projection import worktable
Output
  • Both processes generate proposed orders written to the U581: Projected Proposed Orders Export worktable.

 

 

Cash Allocation Methodologies

Straight Percentage methodology

 

Business Description

The cash available to allocate (liquidity balance) is divided up amongst the investments specified by the Allocation Parameters (ALPs). This creates a proposed order for each investment (application or redemption). This value is written into the ‘Ideal Order’ field on the Proposed Order.

Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings
  • Cashflows (from the U109 or U110 worktables)

Processing Requirements

For each ALP, the straight percentage calculation is:

$Ideal\ Order\ =\ Cash\ available\ to\ allocate\ \times \left ( Target\ Weight\ \%\ or\ Current\ Weight\ \%\ for\ the\ asset \right )$

Where Orders Criteria grouping is selected on the entity, the calculation is:

$Ideal\ Order\ =\ Cash\ available\ to\ allocate\ for\ order\ criteria\ group\ \times \left ( Target\ Weight\ \%\ or\ Current\ Weight\ \%\ for\ the\ asset \right )$

The entity attribute Straight Percentage Weight Method determines if Target or Current weight from the ALPs is used in the calculation.

Entity Data Attributes Used

 Straight Percentage Methodology

The following attributes are used by all cash allocation methodologies (unless otherwise specified):

  • Allocation Methodology
    • Select methodology.
  • Allocation Grouping
    • The setting of this attribute will have an impact on the price date on the proposed order and subsequent actual order. This applies to both cash allocation and rebalancing runs.

    Effective Date

    The effective date allocation grouping will create orders from the fund with a price date equal to the effective date. This is the same as normal cash allocation, i.e. no deferral of cash allocation orders is required.

    Forward

    The forward allocation grouping will create orders from the fund with a price date equal to the greatest deferral (notice) date on the bottom-most-level asset invested in. The settlement date on the proposed order will equal to the ‘Value Date’ configured on the asset entity level.

    Historic

    The historic allocation grouping will create orders from the fund with a price date equal to the last approved price date of the asset. This is similar to standard cash allocation, i.e. no deferral of cash allocation orders is required, although an historic price may be used if historic allocation grouping is specified.

    Forward and Historic

    If ‘Forward and Historic’ allocation grouping is selected, then two cashflows groups from the fund will be created – one containing orders with a forward (deferred price) date, and another with a historic (last approved price) date.

    Orders Criteria

    The ‘Orders Criteria’ allocation grouping uses the allocation criteria in the Orders Criteria attribute table to determine how the incoming cashflows are processed. This ensures that the relevant price date, transaction type or price type for any cashflows received is applied consistently throughout the investment structure.

    Blank

    If left blank, pControl will default to 'Effective Date'.

  • Straight Percentage Weight Method
    •   Determines whether the Target or Current weight from the ALPs is used in the allocation calculations.

    Target Weight

    pControl will use the value set in ALP

    Current Weight

    pControl will use the Asset Allocation
    Blank

    pControl will default to use Target Weight.


      

 Straight Percentage Methodology with Orders Criteria Grouping

The price or ‘value’ date, transaction type or price type for any cashflows received can be applied to proposed orders generated throughout the investment structure. This means that together with a ‘straight percentage’ method, the cashflows can be further grouped by the specified criteria. The entity attributes are as follows:

  • Allocation Methodology
    • Straight Percentage
  • Allocation Grouping
    • Orders Criteria Grouping
  • Orders Criteria
    •  Ensures that the relevant price or 'value' date, transaction type or price type for any cashflows received is applied throughout the investment structure.

    Price Date

    Refers to the different value dates populated in the 'Price Date' field in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable with the same price date, will be grouped together.

    Price Type

    Refers to the different price type populated in the ‘Price Type’ field in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable. Cashflows with the same price type (e.g. buy price, sell price) will be grouped together.

    Transaction Type

    Refers to the transaction types populated in the ‘Tran Type’ field in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable, together with the transaction types that have been configured in the ‘Group in Cash Allocation’ field in the L250: Transaction Flow Configuration worktable. Cashflows with the same transaction type will be grouped together.

    For example, if Price Date is selected, the cash available to allocate is divided by the price date. The value of orders loaded in each price date group is then processed individually with proposed orders made for each investment according to both the ALP weights and the price date group. Where price date is specified for grouping, a proposed order will be created for each investment with the price date equal to the effective date (application or redemption). The value is then written into the Ideal Order field on the Proposed Order with the price date equal to the effective date.

     

 

 
Zero Cash to Allocate methodology

 

Business Description

This methodology allows users to have the option not to allocate cash to funds when a cash allocation and rebalancing process is run, even though target weights and liquidity have been set up in an ALPs. Proposed orders with zero value will be created, and this provides the opportunity to adjust the proposed order amounts, or to leave the values at zero.

Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings
  • Cashflows (from the U109 or U110 worktables)

Processing Requirements

The ‘Zero Cash to Allocate’ method will simply zero out the ideal order value on the proposed orders, even when there is cash to allocate. The starting position, available cash, etc. remain viewable on the proposed order.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

 
Towards Target methodology

 

Business Description

This methodology allocates cash towards target based on proportional difference to target amounts. Positive cashflows are allocated proportionally to assets underweight, whereas negative cashflows are allocated proportionally to assets that are overweight. Positive cashflows are never allocated to overweight assets and vice versa.

Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings
  • Cashflows (from the U109 or U110 worktables)

Processing Requirements

Where the liquidity balance is positive, proposed orders for underweight assets will be calculated proportionally based on the difference to target amounts. The value of the liquidity balance is always included in the calculation of the start weights (and thus the difference to target amounts). The underweight asset that is farthest from target will get the largest allocation of cash.

Note, this is NOT a ranked methodology in which the asset that is farthest from target is first brought all the way to target, and so on.

Allocation of cash is proportional to all eligible assets based upon difference to target amounts. Cash that cannot be allocated (in the event that all assets are at their target) will either remain in liquidity or be allocated as per the spare cash methodology defined on the entity.

The same methodology and behaviour applies for negative cashflows.

If Cash to Allocate > 0 and Difference to Target < 0, then ideal order =

$Cashflow\ Amount\ \times \large \left ( \frac{ Difference\ to\ Target\ for\ ALR }{Total\ Difference\ to\ Target\ for\ all\ Unders} \right )$

If Cash to Allocate < 0 and Difference to Target > 0, then ideal order =

$Cashflow\ Amount\ \times \large \left ( \frac{ Difference\ to\ Target\ for\ ALR }{Total\ Difference\ to\ Target\ for\ all\ Overs} \right )$

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

 
Box Management methodology

 

Business Description

The ‘Box Management’ methodology in the pControl cash allocation product supports the ability of using a manager’s box within an investment structure to effectively trade and manage liquidity on behalf of the manager.

This strategy is typically used in UK Life Company environments to support trading limits.
Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings
  • Transaction orders generated from above/within the structure from entities

Processing Requirements

When Box Management is selected, any 'excess' at the box level is used to produce an order to maintain the box limits. The trades from/to the box are handled according to standard box rules, selected on the box entity.

Note: If Use Box Management Limits from Parents is selected, the box limits from the ALP originator are used.

The box position is calculated as follows:

$Investment\ Holdings\ Value\ -\ Total\ Unapproved\ Orders\ -\ Total\ Calculated\ Proposed\ Orders$

If Include Liquidity Balance from asset is selected, then any liquidity balances from the non-liquidity asset for the entity is added to the box position.

If the box position is outside of minimum and maximum trading limits, a proposed order is generated to maintain the Box position. The proposed order amount is calculated by:

$Box\ Position\ +\ Target\ \times -1$

The Deal Multiple function is used to round off the proposed order. Any excess after rounding is written as a write-off journal to the fund's account balances. Where creating a unit based order, the journal amount is converted to a cash value using the Price Type set on the entity's Price Type to Value Investment Holdings attribute, as follows:

$Number\ of\ Units \times Last\ Approved\ Price\ $

Box Management Example

The Manager's Box, the counterparty, is selling 100 units of Australian Shares to Balanced Fund. The steps and options

 

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Load Calculated and Approved Proposed Orders from Investors
    • When selected, the cash allocation process for Balanced Fund is completed first before looking to the 'Box Management Rules' attribute to determine the next step.
  • Box Management Rules
    • If a different set of rules is to apply to the box, then alternative rules can be written.
  • Box Management Limits
    • Default Pricing Basis The default pricing basis price type is defined in the 'Daily Pricing' attributes used in swing pricing. The box management limits row for this price type are then used when box trades are created.
    Max LimitThe maximum value of trades generated from the box.
    Min LimitThis is the minimum value of trades generated from the box.
    Deal MultipleThe number used to round the trade so that it is a multiple of a particular value.
    TargetThe target value to be held by the box.
    Dealing BasisIndicates whether the box limit values are in cash or units.
  • Write off Transaction Type
    • The write amount is calculated as $Box\ position\ -\ \left ( Target\ +\ Trade \right )$
    This attribute defines the transaction type that the journal is written for.
  • Use Box Management limits from parent
    • If selected, the process will use the Box Management Limits from the originator from the allocation parameters where the current entity is the counterparty. 

 

Rebalancing Methodologies

Rebalance to Target methodology

 

Business Description

Rebalancing is usually performed to re-weight any investment holdings that are out of tolerance. In pControl, this process calculates and creates proposed orders in the same way as Cash Allocation.

For each Allocation Parameter (ALP), pControl checks whether the starting position in each asset specified by the ALP is outside of the tolerances that have been set, i.e. the following test is performed.
Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings

Processing Requirements

A rebalance will be initiated if any of the starting positions are outside of tolerance, including liquidity. If there is an amount in cash when the rebalancing runs, and it is outside of the upper tolerance, then the rebalance will generate a proposed order to bring the holding to within the upper limit.

If $Start\ Weight\ \% < \left ( TW\ -\ Lower\ Tolerance \right )$ OR $Start\ Weight\ \% >\ \left ( TW\ +\ Upper\ Tolerance \right )$

then, propose a rebalancing order.

If $\left ( TW\ -\ Lower\ Tolerance \right ) \leqslant\ Start\ Weight\ \% \leqslant\ \left(TW\ +\ Upper\ Tolerance \right)$

then the investment is within tolerance, and a rebalance will not be proposed.

For each investment that has been identified as outside of tolerance, the calculation is as follows:

$Ideal\ Order\ =\ \left (TW\ \times Total\ Investment\ Value\ of\ the\ fund \right )\ -\ Starting\ value\ of\ investment\ in\ the\ asset$

Ad-hoc Rebalancing

Ad-hoc Rebalancing functionality allows funds to request rebalancing outside of their standard schedule rebalancing periods, with special allocation parameters used, if required, to override the default strategy and tolerances. Ad-hoc rebalancing is supported by both Rebalance to Target and Partial Rebalance to Percent Target methodologies.

A Rebalancing Calendar can be defined by using a ‘Calendar Schedule Entity’. The calendar schedule entity contains the calendar which determines the scheduled days when ad-hoc rebalancing should be allowed to run. For example, where a scheduled rebalance occurs on a public holiday, the default may move this rebalancing event to the next working day, however ad-hoc rebalancing can override this event, so that the rebalancing process takes place on the public holiday.

 

 Miss a Scheduled Rebalance

If selected, the rebalancing process will not run if an ad-hoc rebalance process has been run since the last rebalancing process.

 

 Nudge Rebalancing (Glide Path)

The daily nudge method uses a series of short-term daily rebalance events over a defined period to gradually move from the original weighting to the new target allocations. For the period between receipt of the request for change and the end date, predefined target allocations (ALPs) will be used to achieve a gradual switch of assets from one fund to another each day until the target is achieved. This is known as the ‘glide path’.

At the end of the period, the fund may revert to use the ALPs that were in place prior to the nudge rebalancing occurring, or the target ALPs can be reset to ensure that the new target allocations are used.

There are two nudge rebalancing methods:

Cash Flow Method

When the glide path method is ‘Cash Flow’, the investment manager is able to specify a target asset allocation that they want to move to, and a timescale (glide path) over which they want to achieve this transition.

When the current (Rebalancing) Allocation Methodology is ‘Straight Percentage’ and the rebalancing falls within the glide path period, pControl will change the allocation methodology from ‘Straight Percentage’ to ‘Towards Target’. Therefore, on a daily basis, the cash allocation process will utilise the net new money and allocate to either the most underweight or most overweight depending on the cash flow for the day.

The Towards Target methodology will check if the new holding is overweight or underweight, and readjust the proposed order amount by giving a proportionate amount to the other under/overweight ALPs

On the last day of the glide path period, the rebalancing process will rebalance using the ALPs that are effective on the glide path end date.

 

 Rebalancing Method

When the glide path method is ‘Rebalancing’, and it is in a glide path period, the investment manager is able to specify a target asset allocation that they want to move to and a timescale over which they want to achieve this transition.

On a daily basis, the cash allocation process will perform the necessary rebalancing transactions to take the fund back to the calculated target asset allocations. Tolerances may be applied on a daily basis but it is likely that they will be set to zero during the duration of the rebalance, to allow a rebalance to occur each day.

Rebalancing will occur to the calculated glide path ALPs for each day in the period.

 

 

 Calculating Glide Path ALPs

The ALPs that are used during the glide path period are calculated for each day in the period and depend on the glide path method that is used, i.e. Cash Flow or Rebalancing.

When it is NOT the last day in the glide period and irrelevant of cashflow or rebalancing method selected, the calculation is:

$TW\ =\ Start\ Date\ TW\ +\ \frac{ \large \left ( End\ Date\ TW -\ Start\ Date\ TW \right ) }{ \left ( \large Total\ Duration\ Glide\ Path\ \times Current\ Day\ in\ Glide\ Path \right ) }$

Where:

  • TW = Target Weight
  • Start Date TW is the ALP attribute effective at the start date of the nudge period
  • End Date TW is the ALP attribute effective at the end date of the nudge period
  • Total Duration Glide Path is the Total number of days in the nudge period inclusive of the start and end date
  • Current Day in Glide Path is the Current day number in the period.

When it IS the last day in the glide period, and the Cash Flow method is used:

$TW\ =\ End\ Date\ TW$

where the End Date TW is the ALP attribute effective at the End Date of the nudge period.

Example:

  Target Weight %
  ALP 1 ALP 2
Opening Target Weights 70 30
05/11/2019 Start of the Glide Path 65 35
06/11/2019 60 40
07/11/2019 55 45
08/11/2019 50 50
09/11/2019 45 55
10/11/2019 End of the Glide Path and End Target Weight 40 60

 

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

 
Partial Rebalance to Percent Target methodology

 

Business Description

The ‘Partial Rebalance to % Target’ methodology checks each Allocation Parameter (ALP) to determine whether the starting position into the asset specified by the ALP is outside of the tolerances that have been set.

The logic for determining if a rebalance is required is the same as the 'Rebalance to Target' methodology. Rather than assets being brought fully to the target weight, they are brought as a percentage to target (as defined on the entity).
Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings

Processing Requirements

If any investment is identified as being outside of tolerance, an ‘Ideal Order’ is calculated for all investments as follows:

$ \left ( Partial\ Rebalance\ Weight\ in\ asset\ \times Total\ Investment\ Value\ of\ the\ fund\ \right ) -\ Starting\ Value\ of\ the\ Investment\ in\ the\ asset$

Where, Partial Rebalance Weight in asset is calculated as:

$Percent\ Towards\ Target\ \times Target\ Weight\ in\ asset\ + \left ( 1\ -\ Percent\ Towards\ Target \right ) \times\ Starting\ Position$

Where, Starting Position is the % value.

Example

Where the Percent towards target is 40%.

Rebalance between Tolerance Limit and Target methodology

 

Business Description

The ‘Rebalance between Tolerance Limit and Target’ methodology will bring assets to a weight that is between the tolerance limit and the target.

Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings

Processing Requirements

The percentage between the tolerance limit and target is defined on the entity using the attribute 'Percent towards Target'.

For example:

  • An asset has a target of 50 and an upper and lower tolerance of 10
  • The percent towards target is set at 50%
  • Current asset weight is 75% which breaches upper tolerance
  • The end weight for the rebalance will be 55%.

Where the requirement is to rebalance all assets when one asset is outside tolerances, the following constraints apply:

  • There cannot be any excluded or Not Tradeable assets
  • The tolerance limits must be the same for all assets.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Percent towards Target is required to be defined on the processing entity

Where an asset cannot be traded, the following attributes are used:

  • Not Tradeable defined as part of the Excluded Asset and Target Group table under the Common tab.
    • When selected, the asset will be excluded from trading during Rebalancing, however the weights of the other assets in the fund will NOT be refactored.

 
Rebalance using Non-Refactored Weights methodology

 

Business Description

The ‘Rebalance using Non-Refactored Weights’ methodology calculates proposed orders on non-refactored target and start weights of the tradeable assets i.e. the methodology does not refactor weights when there are assets in the portfolio that cannot be traded.
Data Requirements
  • Allocation Parameters (including liquidity entity)
  • Investment Holdings balances
  • Approved prices for investment holdings
  • A minimum of one asset is flagged as Not Tradeable

Processing Requirements

The methodology does not refactor weights when there are assets in the portfolio that cannot be traded. These assets are flagged as Not Tradeable on the entity template, as opposed to Excluded. Weights are not refactored in order to satisfy the following criteria:

  • Rebalancing decisions are based upon actual start and target weights and not the refactored weights.
  • Assets that are already underweight are never traded.
  • Assets are never traded beyond their target weights as a result of refactored weights.
  • Liquidity is prioritised on assets that are the farthest from their target.

For Tradeable assets in the portfolio, calculate:

$abs\ \sum\ Underweight\ +\ Overweight\ Difference\ to\ Target\ amounts$

Calculate proposed orders to bring assets to target weight:

$Proposed\ Order\ =\ End\ Weight\ -\ Start\ Weight$

If an asset is outside upper tolerance then,

$End\ Weight\ =\ \left [ Target\ Weight\ +\ Upper\ Tolerance\ - \left ( \frac{ \large\ Upper\ Tolerance\ \times Percent\ Towards\ Target}{100} \right ) \right ]$

If an asset is outside lower tolerance then,

$End\ Weight\ =\ \left [ Target\ Weight\ -\ Lower\ Tolerance\ + \left ( \large \frac{Lower\ Tolerance\ \times Percent\ Towards\ Target}{100} \right ) \right ]$

The leg with the lesser absolute value is able to be brought fully to target as there is equal and/or more to calculate offsetting proposed orders.

The next step will prioritise the breached assets of the offsetting leg.

Any remaining cash is allocated proportionally across all assets of the 'offsetting leg' that are still over/under weight, but not in breach.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Excluded and Not Tradeable are defined as part of the Excluded Asset and Target Group table under the Common tab.

 

Common Functions on the Processing Entity

There are functions on the ‘Common’ tab of an entity e.g. ‘Base Currency’ and the sub tabs of Common e.g. ‘Foreign Exchange’, ‘Cash Allocation & Rebalancing’ etc. These common attributes are shared across all processes that are run for the entity (cash allocation and any other processes being run e.g. unit pricing).

Excluded Asset and Target Group

 

Business Description

Processing Detail

 Target groups

Target Groups are required when one or more entities within a nominal group have the 'Exclude this asset from Cash Allocation and Rebalancing' attribute selected, and the end weight of the group of assets needs to match the target weight of the group. When an excluded asset is part of a group, a different rebalancing formula is applied to the entities within the target group.

  • Entities with the same value in the 'Target Group' field are said to belong to the same group.
  • An entity can only belong to one Target Group.
  • Destination FROM and Destination TO entities cannot belong to the same group.
  • An excluded asset could belong to a group. When this occurs, that entity's value is not removed from the total investment balance, however an adjustment is made to the calculation of those entities that belong to a group.

 

 Target groups by plan and by originator

Target groups and excluded assets can be defined on a plan basis or by originator. This enables processing where a number of assets that are held across multiple plans, only belong to a target group in some of those plans. It is possible to define the plan or originator for the asset that should be included in the target group.

Note: Within a multi-originator structure, the plan is the parent of an asset. Within a single originator structure, the plan is the originator.

For example, when there are target groups with excluded assets, they are refactored and the included assets within the group are set to equal the total target weight of the group. This means that the current weights within the target group are refactored and the CAR process is using both refactored target weights and refactored current weights.

The actual weight of assets in target groups must be refactored, using the following calculation:

$\small Refactored \ Actual\ Weight\ = \small Actual\ Start\ Weight\ of\ the\ Asset\ + Excluded\ Weights\ in\ the\ Target\ Group\ \left (\normalsize \frac{Target\ Weight\ of\ the \ Asset}{Non-Excluded\ Target\ Weight\ of\ the\ Asset} \right )$

The current weights are refactored based on the percentage allocation of the refactored target weights.

$\small Refactored \ Current\ Weight\ of\ the\ Aset\ = Current\ Weight\ of\ the\ Asset \left ( 1\ + \left (\normalsize \frac{Sum\ of\ Excluded\ Current\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group}{Sum\ of\ Non-Excluded\ Current\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group} \right ) \right )$

The Refactored Current Weight is then used to calculate the proposed orders.

$CW_i\ =\ Current\ Weight\ for\ Asset\ i \\ rCW_i\ =\ Refactored\ Current\ Weight\ for\ Asset\ i \\ eCW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Excluded\ Assets\ Current\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group \\ nCW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Non-Excluded\ Assets\ Current\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group $

 

 Spare Cash Reallocation Method 'Move to Target'

If all assets that can be traded have a difference to target of 0.00% (i.e. when there is spare cash on a rebalance) then the following will occur:

  • If the spare cash value is positive, the cash allocation process allocates it to the first asset with a negative proposed order amount that can cover the full amount of the spare cash.
  • If the spare cash value is negative, the cash allocation process allocates it to the first asset with a positive proposed order amount of the spare cash.
  • If no individual asset can cover the full amount of spare cash, the value is maintained in liquidity and the spare cash is not reallocated.

If assets that can be traded have difference to target amounts <>0.00%, i.e. spare cash on cash allocation, then the following will occur:

  • If the spare cash value is positive, the asset that is the most underweight i.e. furthest from the target, will receive the spare cash.
  • If there is enough cash to bring the asset to target and cash remains, the asset that is the second furthest from the target, will be allocated the spare cash.
  • Any remaining cash at this point will remain in liquidity.
  • If the spare cash value is negative, the above behaviour applies to assets that are overweight.

Note: The spare cash reallocation method described differs from Cash Allocation Towards Target methodology in which the cash is always allocated proportionally.

 

 Spare Cash from Rounding

If spare cash is 0.05 (absolute value) or less, then it is treated as rounding and is allocated to the largest ALP holding. If the value is greater than 0.05 and cannot be allocated to the largest holding, it will remain in liquidity.

 

 Spare Cash Reallocation 'Move to Target' with Excluded Asset and Target Groups

If an entity invests into assets where some assets are excluded, but not within target groups, the value of the excluded asset is not included in the calculation of difference to target (and is based off the refactored targets and weights).

If an entity invests into assets where some assets are excluded and are in target groups, the difference to target amounts are calculated from refactored target and current weights. Where there are target groups, the value of the excluded assets is included in these calculations and pControl will spread the total assets of the group over the non-excluded assets using the refactored actual weight calculation.

 Refactoring target weight calculations

Refactoring occurs when an excluded asset that has a non-zero weight, has its weight assigned to the other assets within the target group, and its weight set to zero. These refactored target weights are then used in the cash allocation process so that no cash flow is assigned to the excluded assets.

The following terms are used in the example below.

$TW_i\ =\ Target\ Weight\ for\ Asset\ i \\ rTW_i\ =\ Refactored\ Target\ Weight\ for\ Asset\ i \\ eTW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Excluded\ Assets\ Target\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group \\ nTW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Non-Excluded\ Assets\ Target\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group $

Note: When an asset is refactored, its tolerances and bounds will be adjusted by the same proportions. An example is provided under Refactoring tolerances and bounds below.

 

The calculation to refactor the target weight is:

$\small rTW_i\ =\ TW_i\ \times \left (1\ +\ \normalsize \frac{eTW_G}{nTW_G} \right )$

Asset 4 has a weight of 18.3% to be assigned to the other assets within the target group. Asset 4's target weight will become zero and all remaining assets within the group will have their weights refactored using the above calculation.

Therefore, Asset 1's refactored target weight becomes 47.18%.

 Refactoring tolerances and bounds

When an asset is refactored, its tolerances and bounds can be adjusted by the same proportions using the 'Accept/Reject Refactored Tolerances and Bounds' function on the Cash Allocation process template. .

 

 Rebalancing calculations

The refactored target weights, described above, are used in the rebalancing formula. The calculation for the rebalanced value of an asset is:

$rVAL_i\ =\ \left ( VAL\ \times \ TW_G\ -\ EXC_G \right ) \times \ \large \frac{rTW_i}{TW_G}$

Where:

$TW_i\ =\ Target\ Weight\ for\ Asset\ i \\ rTW_i\ =\ Refactored\ Target\ Weight\ for\ Asset\ i \\ eTW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Excluded\ Assets\ Target\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group \\ nTW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Non-Excluded\ Assets\ Target\ Weights\ for\ the\ Group \\ rVAL_i\ =\ The\ Rebalanced\ Value\ of\ Asset\ i \\ VAL\ =\ The\ total\ value\ of\ the\ plan\ i.e.\ the\ sum\ of\ the\ value\ of\ all\ assets \\ TW_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ the\ Assets\ Refactored\ Target\ Weights\ for\ the\ group \\ EXC_G\ =\ The\ Sum\ of\ Value\ of\ the\ Excluded\ Assets\ for\ the\ group $

 

 No excluded assets and no groups

Where there are no excluded assets, there is no requirement to form a target group.

$rVAL_i\ =\ (VAL\ \times TW_i)$

Not Tradeable

 

Business Description

When selected, no proposed order is calculated for the asset during the rebalancing process and weights are not refactored.

Processing Detail

When both Excluded and Not Tradeable functions are selected on the entity, the asset will be excluded from trading during the Cash Allocation process only, therefore no refactoring will occur on this asset during the Rebalancing process.

When Excluded is selected only, the asset will be excluding from trading during the Cash Allocation and Rebalancing processes.

Note: Where an asset is selected as Not Tradeable, the Target Groups functionality and Refactoring for Transaction Minimum/Maximum Constraints functionality, cannot be applied.

Cash Allocation Functions on the Processing Entity

Each entity in pControl has a number of functions (or attributes) associated with it and these are used for a variety of purposes; from supporting processing to providing information for querying and reporting.

The values and settings of these functions, which are sometimes in combination with the processing template settings, will affect the behaviour and results of the cash allocation and rebalancing processes.

Compliance Checks

 

Business Description

The compliance checks determine if the value of an asset or sector moves outside of the limits and therefore whether or not the order is approved.

Note: this function is located on the entity and not the process template.

Processing Detail

The Investment level and up to 5 classification checks can be configured in pControl.

For each check configured, the breach level and severity level require to be defined. The severity level defines what occurs when the actual weight breaches tolerances or bounds.

  • Soft breaches can be overridden, to allow an order to be approved.
  • Hard breaches cannot be overridden. Instead, the order's value needs to be changed to move the entity's value and the classification's value back inside the limits.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Compliance Checks

Breach Level
  • Tolerances are the percentage movements away from a target where the portfolio is considered outside.
  • Bounds are absolute upper and lower limit where the portfolio is considered out of bounds.
Severity Level
  • Soft breaches can be overridden, to allow an order to be approved.
  • Hard breaches cannot be overridden. Instead, the order's value needs to be changed to move the entity's value and the classification's value back inside the limits.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
Linking Proposed Orders on Interfund Structures using External ID

 

Business Description

An External ID can be used in order to link proposed orders within interfund structures.

Note: this function is located on the entity and not on the process template.

Processing Detail

The diagram below shows an interfund structure and how it is linked using the External ID. All ALRs within the structure have their own unique ALR ID, but they all share the same External ID that has been provided for the initial cashflow via the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable. The External ID can be input or imported via the U110: Cashflows and Orders import workable.

If an External ID is not provided via the U110: Cashflows and Orders, pControl will generate a unique ID once the CAR process is run.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

Interdependencies
  • Orders Criteria
    • This function provides the ability to process cashflows individually when running CAR via the 'External ID' Orders Criteria allocation method.

Prerequisite Functions
  • U110: Cashflows and Orders

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
Processing Cashflows Individually

 

Business Description

pControl provides the ability to process cashflows individually when running CAR via the 'External ID' Orders Criteria allocation method.

Note: this function is located on the entity and not on the process template.

Processing Detail

This method requires an external ID on all U110 cashflows, as detailed in Linking Proposed Orders on Interfund Structures using External ID (add link), and the cash is processed in ascending order of the External IDs.

When External ID is selected, the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable records for the same entity and same effective date are processed individually within the same CAR run as follows:

  • Load Allocation Parameters.
  • Load Investment Holdings.
  • Load Liquidity Account Balances.
  • Calculate Proposed Orders for first cash flow.
  • Where cash allocation method is "Towards Target", Investment holdings will need to be recalculated or reloaded.
  • The CAR process will loop through and calculate proposed orders for the next cash flow, until complete.
  • A set of proposed orders for each cash flow (External ID) will be created within the single CAR run.
  • There will only be one master record per entity per CAR Run Date.
  • External ID will be associated with every proposed order for the entire interfund structure.

Note: The CAR process will always run for the entire interfund structure in a top down manner, regardless of which entities are receiving cash.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

Interdependencies
  • Orders Criteria
    • This function provides the ability to process cashflows individually when running CAR via the 'External ID' Orders Criteria allocation method.

Prerequisite Functions
  • U110: Cashflows and Orders

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
Minimum Total Orders

 

Business Description

The Minimum Cash Total Orders functions in both Cash Allocation and Rebalancing processes allow a minimum order to be applied for an originator entity from a compliance check carried out pre-approval to identify whether or not the minimum is met. Where the minimum is met, the transactions will be processed.

Note: this function is located on the entity and not on the process template.

Processing Detail

This function ensures that all orders over multiple assets total more than the Minimum Total Order for the Originator. The value of the minimum total order is the greater of the two attributes 'Minimum Total Orders ($) and Minimum Total Orders (% of investment holdings).

Where the minimum is not met, the orders will be moved to an exception state. It is possible to override or reject the proposed orders.

Example to demonstrate where proposed orders are more than the minimum total value order ($)

Cash at Bank

Cashflows today

Total Cashflow

$250,000

$10,000

$260,000

Minimum Cash Balance

$1,500,000

Over/under cash

$260,000-$1,500,000 = -$1,240,000 (redemption)

Note: This total is made up of two redemption orders or -100,000 from Fund A and 1,140,000 from Fund B.

Minimum Originator Orders

$200,000

Test over/under cash with Minimum Order

abs(-1,240,000)>abs(200,000) = TRUE

Therefore, orders can be placed for a redemption of $1,240,000

 

 Example where proposed orders do not meet the minimum originator order ($) and an exception is raised

Cash at Bank

Cashflows today

Total Cashflow

$1,495,000

$10,000

$1,505,000

Minimum Cash Balance

$1,500,000

Over/under cash

$1,505,000-$1,500,000 = -$5,000

Minimum Originator Orders

$200,000

Test over/under cash with Minimum Order

abs(5,000)>abs(200,000) = FALSE

Therefore, the minimum originator order is not met and an exception is raised.

 

 Example where minimum originator order is not met and an exception is raised

Cash at Bank

Cashflows today

Total Cashflow

$1,495,000

-$10,000

$1,485,000

Minimum Cash Balance

$1,500,000

Over/under cash

$1,485,000-$1,500,000 = -$15,000

Minimum Originator Orders

$200,000.00

Test over/under cash with Minimum Order

abs(-15,000)>abs(200,000) = FALSE

Therefore, the minimum originator order is not met and an exception is raised.

Note that despite being under the cash minimum of $1,500,000.00, a redemption is NOT raised for the minimum cash order.

 

 Example where minimum originator order is not met and an exception is raised

Rebalancing Application

Rebalancing Redemption

Total Cashflow

$1,595,000

-$100,000

$595,000

Minimum Originator Orders

$600,000

Test over/under cash with Minimum Order

abs(595,000)>abs(600,000) = FALSE

Therefore, the minimum originator order is not met and an exception is raised.

The value of the minimum total order is the greater of the two attributes 'Minimum Total Order ($) and Minimum Total Orders (%).

 

Note: Where using the 'Minimum Total Orders (%)' attribute, the value is determined by multiplying the percentage value by the investment holdings value.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Exclude Unapproved Orders
    • If selected, unapproved orders will not be included in the cash to allocate calculation, i.e. where registry orders are not configured to be created in an 'Approved' state and have not been manually transitioned to 'Approve'.
  • Minimum Cash Balance
    • In the example, the entity will always maintain a cash /liquidity balance of $1,500,000.00
  • Minimum Total Orders
    • When populated, this function allows a minimum order to be applied for an originator entity from a compliance check carried out pre-approval to identify whether or not the minimum is met. Where the minimum is met, the transactions will be processed. This function ensures that all orders over multiple assets total more than the Minimum Total Order for the Originator. The value of the minimum total order is the greater of the two attributes 'Minimum Total Orders ($) and Minimum Total Orders (% of investment holdings). Where the minimum is not met, the orders will be moved to an exception state. It is possible to override or reject the proposed orders.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • U110: Cashflows and Orders

Outputs
  • Process status messages

 
Refactor Weights for Transaction Minimum/Maximum Constraints

 

Business Description

pControl allows for the refactoring of weights where there are transaction minimum and maximum breaches.

Note: this function is located on the entity and not on the process template.

Processing Detail

Where transaction minimum constraints are not met, the assets that do not meet the constraints will have their target and actual weights set to 0.00 and the weights of the tradeable assets within the portfolio or target group will be refactored. The total cash is reallocated based on the refactored target and actual weights. This is demonstrated in the examples below.

In cases where the asset with the transaction minimum/maximum constraint is part of a target group, the refactoring and reallocation will occur within the target group (as in the case of excluded assets that are part of a target group). If reallocation cannot occur within the target group, then the cash will either remain in liquidity or be allocated as per the spare cash methodology defined on the entity.

In rebalance scenarios where there is only one (or none) tradeable asset due to the transaction minimum/maximum constraints, then no rebalance will occur i.e. proposed orders for 0.00.

Transaction Minimum - Examples

In the case of a transaction minimum, the entire amount of the suggested proposed order goes to either liquidity or spare cash. The Refactor Weights for Constraints attributes provides the option to treat spare cash as a result of a transaction minimum as an 'Excluded Asset' for a given entity.

Where the transaction minimum constraints are not met, the assets that do not meet the transaction minimum constraints will have their target and actual weights set to 0.00 and the weights of the tradeable assets within the portfolio/target group will be refactored. The total cash would then be reallocated based upon the refactored target and actual weights.

When the 'Refactor Weights for Transaction Minimum /Maximum Constraints' is set to true, any proposed order that does not meet the transaction minimum/maximum criteria will not go into spare cash or liquidity. The assets will be treated as an 'Excluded Asset', and pControl will refactor the target and actual weights and then reallocate across the portfolio/target group.

Example

In the following tables, Refactored is shortened to Rf.

Where the transaction minimum is $75,000.00 for Asset 2 and the Straight Percentage -Target Weight methodology is applied.

 Transaction Minimum and Maximum - Rebalancing examples

If only one asset is tradeable in a rebalance scenario due to minimum/maximum constraints, proposed orders should not be generated therefore no rebalance is performed. If after the final iteration of refactoring weights due to transaction minimum/maximum constraints, there are not at least two tradeable assets, then no rebalance occurs.

Where there are transaction minimums and no rebalance can occur, after the first iteration of refactoring the weights, further transaction minimum constraints are breached. The only tradeable asset is Asset 4, so no rebalance can occur.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Refactor Weights for Transaction Minimum/Maximum Constraints
    • When selected, any asset that has hit a transaction minimum or maximum will be treated as 'Excluded'. This means current and target weights will be refactored, and a new set of proposed orders will be generated.
    If set to false, whatever cannot be allocated due to the minimum/maximum will be treated as spare cash.

    • Allocation up to the Maximum pControl will treat the asset as excluded, but first allocate up to the maximum amount.

Outputs

Rebalancing Functions on the Processing Entity

Each entity in pControl has a number of functions (or attributes) associated with it and these are used for a variety of purposes; from supporting processing to providing information for querying and reporting.

The values and settings of these functions, which are sometimes in combination with the processing template settings, will affect the behaviour and results of the rebalancing process.

Trade Lowest Cost Asset

 

Business Description

This function allows for an offsetting trade that is required to bring the cash holding back within tolerances to be made against the lowest cost non-cash asset within the portfolio. The assets within the portfolio are ranked such that the lowest cost asset has the highest ranking, where the highest ranking is 1. Ranking is maintained on the ALP.

This function should only be used in conjunction with the 'Rebalance against Cash' feature, in which only assets that are outside tolerances are rebalanced.

Processing Detail

When the rebalancing process is executed, and the Trade Lowest Cost Asset is selected, the process will determine if the cash entity is inside or outside tolerances after non-cash assets have been rebalanced. The 'cash entity' can either be a designated cash holding or the liquidity entity.

Note: This function is used in conjunction with the 'Rebalance against Cash' function. When selected, only assets that are outside tolerances are rebalanced, rather than all assets being rebalanced if a single asset is outside tolerances.

The ranking order is maintained on the ALP, where 1 is the highest rank and 10 is the lowest rank (in a scenario where assets are ranked from 1-10).

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Trade Lowest Cost Asset

Interdependencies
  • Rebalance Against Cash is required to be selected.

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • nil

 

Functions on the Cash Allocation Process Template

Validity Checks

The Process Validation phase initialises i.e. sets up the environment so that the processing can take place successfully and performs some checks to ensure that it is valid for the process to be running on a particular entity.

[PRV010] - Check if Entity is set for Cash Allocation

 

Business Description

This function checks whether the entity is configured to be included in Cash Allocation processing.

Processing Detail

If selected, processing will continue.

If not selected, processing will stop.
Validation Formula (will fail if)  

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Include in Processing
    • This attribute determines whether the entity should be included in the processing run. This attribute is particularly useful when processing is requested on a group entity. The bulk submit process will check this attribute to determine whether to process all entities within the group, or only a selection of the entities.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • nil

 
[PRV020] - Check if Valid Cash Allocation Day

 

Business Description

This check tests whether the processing day (effective date) that a process is being run for is a valid processing day for the entity.

Processing Detail

Calendar data is required for both the Cash Allocation and Rebalancing processes to allow them to run on different frequencies e.g. Cash Allocation on a straight percentage basis may run each day and then Rebalancing may occur once a month.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Cash Allocation Calendar
    • The calendar, or calendar schedule entity, (overlay of working days and holiday days) defines the working and holiday dates. If the Use Alternate Calendar Source attribute is selected, valid working days will be sourced from the L390: Working Days worktable.

  • Rebalancing Calendar
    • On the Rebalancing tab, the calendar, or calendar schedule entity, defines the working and holiday dates. If the Use Alternate Calendar Source attribute is selected, valid working days will be sourced from the L390: Working Days worktable.


    With Ad-hoc Rebalancing, ‘Rebalancing Calendar Schedule Entity’ is used to govern when ad-hoc rebalancing should be allowed to run.

  • If the processing day is a valid rebalancing day according to the rebalancing calendar schedule entity, the rebalancing process will continue.
  • If the processing day is NOT a valid rebalancing day, the master proposed orders will be set to ‘Finish’ and the rebalancing process will end with no proposed orders created.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
[PRV030] - Check if multiple runs are allowed for a day

 

Business Description

This function will validate that the process has been run previously for the entity on the same date.

Processing Detail

pControl records (as an external balance) the number of times the process has been run.

If selected, pControl will validate that the record has a greater external balance than 1 thus testing whether there has been a previous run of the process for the entity on the same date.

If there has not been more than one process run, processing will continue. If there has been more than one process run, the process will then look to the process entity attribute Allow Multiple Cash Allocation Runs on a day to determine whether processing continues.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Allow Multiple Cash Allocation Runs on a Day
    • If selected, processing will continue.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
[PRV035] - Check if multiple unapproved proposed orders are allowed for a day

 

Business Description

This function checks if the entity allows more than one ‘Unapproved Proposed Order’ for a given effective date / originator / counterparty relationship.

Processing Detail

If there is only one Unapproved Proposed Order for the given effective date / originator / counterparty relationship, processing will continue.

If there is more than one Unapproved Proposed Order for the given processing date, the process will check the Allow multiple Unapproved Proposed Orders attribute on the entity to determine whether processing continues.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Allow Multiple Unapproved Proposed Orders
    • If selected, processing will continue.
    If not selected, the previous calculated / unapproved proposed orders will be deleted.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
[PRV050] - Check if external assets have missed cut-off

 

Business Description

This function checks if any external assets this entity may potentially invest into have missed their cut-off for the effective date of the process.

Processing Detail

If the effective date of the cash allocation process = current date, processing will continue.

If the effective date of the cash allocation process < current date, an exception will be raised.

Entity Data Attributes Used

The external asset must contain the following:

  • P1_TRANSACTION_EXTERNAL attribute group
  • Notice Period (offset) value that indicates when the cut-off date is
  • Notice Period cut-off time that indicates the time at which cut-off occurs
  • Notice Period Calendar to be used in conjunction with the Notice Period.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • For the external cut-off to be used, there must be Allocation Parameters defined through to the external assets. There may be several levels of investment before the external assets.

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
[PRV060] - Check if other Cash Allocation process has been run for the day content taken from CA User Guide

 

Business Description

Processing Detail

 

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • C

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 

Data Load

The data load processing phase loads all of the data that is required by the cash allocation and rebalancing process from internal pControl balances and the standard import worktables.

[REG010] - Generate Cashflow Records from Unit Movements

 

Business Description

This function compares the total units on issue loaded today against the total units on issue at the previous working day to calculate a unit inflow or outflow.

Processing Detail

This function is typically used by Life Companies for the generation of cashflow records from unit movements based on unit balances loaded into the U108: Units on Issue input worktable as sourced from Life Company policy administration systems.

Note: The unit inflow / outflow calculated here are used in later functions to calculate a cash amount cashflow record. Refer to [REG020] - Calculate Cash Amounts on Cashflow Records for further detail.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Cashflow Calculations
    • Note: The attributes are located on the policy administration system entity – they define the parameters of the originator of the entries. Multiple policy administration systems can be used to originate these entries. The parameters below can differ depending on the particular policy administration system.

Calculate Cash Amount
  • If this attribute is selected, pControl will calculate a cash amount and populate the ‘Cash Amount’ field together with the field ‘Calculate Cash Amount’ selected in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable.
    •  The cash amount will be calculated based on the unit movements between the two working days, X and the latest available price.
  • If this attribute is not selected, pControl will calculate the unit movements and populate the 'Unit Amount' field.

Positive Transaction Type

The transaction type that should be recorded against the record in the U110 worktable if the value is a positive amount (i.e. Application).

Negative Transaction Type

The transaction type that should be recorded against the record in the U110 worktable if the value is a negative amount (i.e. Redemption).

Price Type

The type of price i.e. Buy Price, Sell Price etc that should be recorded against the record in the U110 worktable.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions

In order for pControl to generate the cashflow records, the following additional data is required.

  • U108 Units on Issue – there should be two records present in the U108 worktable with the ‘Unit Mvt Status’ = ‘L’ (for loading) and ‘Calc Unit Mvt’ selected.

Note: In order to view ‘Unit Mvt Status’ and ‘Calc Unit Mvt’ fields, the U108 worktable must be in ‘Details’ view.

Outputs
  • U110: Cashflows and Orders records containing the unit amount (or with a zero unit amount in preparation for the [REG020] - Calculate Cash Amounts on Cashflow Records).

 
[REG020] - Calculate Cash Amounts on Cashflow Records

 

Business Description

pControl will retrieve the latest approved unit price for the entity, price run type and price date and will use this price to calculate the cash value of the inflow / outflow (to 2dp).

Processing Detail

This function is typically used by Life Companies to convert unit cashflow records created from the 'Generate Cashflow Records from Unit Movements' function into a cash amount, and then record them in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable.

Note: The records in the U110 worktable now contain the cash value and will be used in the [REG030] - Create Registry Order.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

Interdependencies
  • [REG020] - Generate Cashflow Records from Unit Movements
  • When selected, the U110 worktable records have been prepared for the calculation of cash.
  • If not selected, the U110 records can be populated directly for this function to run.

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • The record in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable is updated with the cash value.

 
[REG030] - Create registry orders

 

Business Description

This function is used to create registry orders using the data in the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable. These orders are created via the CAR process based on the ‘Unit Amount’, ‘Cash Amount’ or the combination of both populated in the U110 worktable.

Processing Detail

The registry orders generated simulate the cashflow into the top-level entities that may receive their cash from external registries or transfer agencies, or through direct investment from investors.

Note: This function may also include the creation of ‘Reservation Orders’ if these are included in the U110: Cashflows import worktable. If included, these may be subsequently reversed.

This function incorporates the creation of registry orders into the Cash allocation process, replacing the need to run the general process ‘Create Registry Orders’.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Date to use for Cash Settlement
    • Allows a choice to be made regarding the date that will be used for the cash settlement of registry orders i.e. the ‘Price Date’ or the ‘Effective Date’ of the U110: Cashflows and Orders record which will influence when the registry transaction hits the configured accounts.
    If left blank, 'Price Date' is the default selection.
     
  • Create Registry Orders in Approved Status
    • Registry orders can be created in an ‘Unapproved’ or ‘Approved’ state.
    If selected, the orders will be created with an 'Approved' state.
    If unselected, the default value, the registry orders will be created in an unapproved state.
  • Reservation Order on Transaction Types
    • A reservation is the notification that cash is available to invest or redeem (i.e. for premium receipts, claim notifications and scheme transfers).

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Registry orders into the top-level or receiving funds (for registry cashflows and reservation orders).

[LD005] - Reverse Previous Reservation Orders

 

Business Description

A reservation is the notification that cash is available to invest or redeem (i.e. for premium receipts, claim notifications and scheme transfers). These transactions are not yet recorded in the Policy Administration System (PAS) or Registry, and, as a consequence, there will be no corresponding cash transactions produced by the PAS and advised to pControl for Cash Allocation processing.

The reversal of reservations is typically performed in UK Life Company environments.

Processing Detail

Reservation transactions can be included in the cash allocation process. These transactions can be loaded into pControl from the U110: Cashflows and Orders import worktable and identified through the use of a ‘reservations’ transaction type. The reservations will be created as registry orders and the amount of the order included in the cash to allocate and is allocated to the entity’s assets according to the ALPs and allocation methodology specified.

When selected, the prior day’s reservation transactions will be reversed by writing an order using the ‘reservation reversal transaction type’ that is indicated on the Company Default entity.

It is important that they are reversed out the next day as cash may have been processed through the PAS by then, and the transaction will be double counted if the reservation is not reversed.

The reversal order amount will be identical to the initial reservation order with a transaction type that has been configured in the Company Default entity. The reversal amount is included in the cash to allocate and allocated to the entity’s assets according to the ALPs and allocation methodology specified. However, the ‘Price Date’ on the reservation reversal transaction will be equal to the ‘Trade Date / Confirmation Date’ field.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Reservation Order Transaction Types
    •  A reservation is the notification that cash is available to invest or redeem (i.e. for premium receipts, claim notifications and scheme transfers).

Application Reservation

The transaction type used to reserve an application order (cash to be received) i.e. Reservation_Applications.

Redemption Reservation

The transaction type used to reserve a redemption order (cash to be paid out / redeemed) i.e. Reservation_Redemptions.

Application Reservation Reversal

The transaction type used to reverse an application reservation order (usually the reverse of the application reservation transaction type) i.e. Redemptions.

Redemption Reservation Reversal

The transaction type to reverse a redemption reservation order (usually the reverse of the redemption reservation transaction type) i.e. Applications.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • [REG030] - Create Registry Orders must be selected on the process template.
  • Load reservation transactions to the U110: Cashflows and Orders worktable.

Outputs
  • Details of the reservation order reversals are output to the status messages of the ‘Data Load’ phase of processing.

 
[LD020] - Load Investment Holdings

 

Business Description

This function loads all of the investment holding balances for the entity from pControl (i.e. from internal pControl investment holdings). The investment holding balances are loaded to support the calculation of starting positions for the entity’s investments.

Processing Detail

The value of an entity’s investment holdings is calculated using:

  • ‘Total Units Held’ or ‘Confirmed Units’ (see entity data attributes used)
  • The latest available price of the underlying investments, (see entity data attributes used) using the ‘Price Type’ to value Investment Holdings’ attribute.
  • The price type and price date used are also provided on the proposed order produced by the cash allocation process.
    • Note: If the underlying investments are external products, pControl will support the dealing term price type configured in the dealing term entity.
  • Investment holding balances are converted into the base currency of the entity if the currency of the asset is different from entity’s base currency.
    • Note: If the value of the investment holdings is zero a Warning message will be created i.e. ‘Total Investment holdings is 0’.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Value Pending Units
    • Where this attribute is selected, the investment holdings will be valued using ‘Total Units held’ i.e. confirmed and unconfirmed units.
    Where this attribute is not selected, the investment holdings will be valued using only ‘Confirmed Units’.
  • Include Awaiting Completion Balances
    •  When this attribute is selected the balances of proposed orders in this state are included in the subsequent CAR processing run.
  • Price Type to Value Investment Holdings
    • This attribute contains a list of price types. The investments will be valued using the latest available prices as per the price type attribute selection.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Total Investment Holdings value is calculated and displayed in the processing status message.

 
[LD030] - Load Calculated and Approved Proposed Orders from Investors

 

Business Description

This function ensures that the dependencies within an investment structure are managed ensuring all of the investors into an entity have had their cash processed before the fund starts its cash allocation process.

Processing Detail

If selected, this function ensures that the dependencies within an investment structure are managed in terms of making sure that all of the investors into an entity have had their cash processed before the fund itself starts its cash allocation process.

Note: This function waits for investor proposed orders to be ‘calculated’ or ‘approved’ as the investor can be set to auto approve to a ‘calculated’ or ‘approved’ state. This allows processing to continue regardless of which of these is configured.

Example

Fund 1 is the counterparty and asset and Investor 1 and Investor 2 are the originators. If this function is selected on the process template for Fund 1, the process will stop and wait until Investor 1 and Investor 2 have Calculated, Approved (or Rejected) their orders into Fund 1. Only when orders are in these states will the Cash Allocation process continue and calculate the liquidity balance and starting positions for Fund 1.

Note: Investors 1 and 2 can reject the proposed orders into Fund 1. This evidences their completion of processing allowing processing to continue for Fund 1.

This function will also wait for Calculated, Approved (or Rejected) orders to be present where the entity is the counterparty only in an ALP. This is to support the Box Management methodology.

 

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Automatically Approve Proposed Orders
    • If selected, pControl will automatically approve all proposed orders to a selective state. This function is used in conjunction with the Automatically Approve Proposed Orders to State.
  • Do Not Automatically Approve Proposed Orders
    • If selected, then the proposed orders which have warning types configured in the ‘Issue Warning on these Events’ table on the processing entity, will not be automatically approved. The list of warning types corresponds to the warning event columns displayed in the proposed order. This attribute should be used in conjunction with the Do Not Automatically Approve on Warnings.
  • Automatically Approve Orders
    • This attribute determines whether orders written on approval of the proposed order should be automatically approved. 
  • Do Not Automatically Approve on Warnings
    • This attribute determines which type of order will not be approved on warning status, e.g. All proposed orders or a Single proposed order.
  • Automatically Approve Proposed Orders to State
    • This attribute is used in conjunction with ‘Automatically Approve Proposed Orders’. If populated, the proposed orders will automatically be approved to the selected state, i.e. ‘Approved’, ‘Calculated’.
  • Automatically Approve Non-Orders to State
    • If populated, pControl will automatically approve the non-orders to a selected state, i.e. ‘Approved’, ‘Calculated’.

     

Interdependencies
  • Do Not Automatically Approve Proposed Orders
    • When selected, the Issue Warning on these Events function on the Post-Calculations tab should be populated with the type of warnings to be acted on.

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • nil

 
[LD039] - Load Balancing Options

Processing Detail

This function is applicable for entities which are set up as ‘Default Options’ entities and is used in conjunction with the [LD040] - Wait for Balancing Options function.

When this function is selected, pControl will load the investment structure between the default option entities and their associated investment option entities from the L260: Cash Allocation - Default Options Mappings worktable.

If there is no data present in the L260 worktable, an exception will be raised. The L260 worktable will need to be populated, and the process ‘Run Again’ from the ‘Master Status’ of the master proposed order.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • nil

Interdependencies
