Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • An exception is raised if no data is present.

 
[LD040] - Wait for Balancing Options

 

Business Description

This function uses the L260: Cash Allocation - Default Options worktable and checks whether the associated investment options have all completed their cash allocation process i.e. all of their proposed orders for the processing day are ‘Approved’ or ‘Rejected’.

Processing Detail

This function is applicable for entities which are set up as ‘Default Options’ entities and is used in conjunction with the [LD039] - Load Balancing Options from Originator function.

When this function is selected, pControl will refer to the L260: Cash Allocation - Default Options worktable and check whether the associated investment options have all completed their cash allocation process.

  • If there are no matching investment options found in the L260 worktable for the default option entity being processed, the cash allocation process continues as normal.
  • If there are matching investment options for the default entity in the L260 worktable, and any of the investment options have not completed their cash allocation process, the master proposed order will enter a wait state, waiting for their completion.

Once all of the Investment Option cash allocation processes have completed, the cash allocation process for the default option continues. The process will make all of the reversing transactions from the Investment Options (reversing the proposed orders) using the ‘weight’ set in the static worktable, and will also make the transaction into the ‘Asset Class for Default Option Offset Trade’ entity if this attribute has been set on the entity.

If the ‘Asset Class for Default Option Offset Trade’ attribute has not been set, then the value of the reversing transaction becomes part of the liquidity of the Default Option when it does its own cash allocation process.

After completion of this function, the cash allocation process for the Default Option moves on and completes any other functions as dictated by the processing template configuration.
Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Check Offsetting Trades
    • If selected for the default option entities, offsetting trades for all default options are checked for rounding issues.
  • Retrieve and Approve Offsetting Trades to State
    • This attribute determines the trade state of the offsetting trades and the trade state of the proposed orders that will be offsetting.

    Blank

    A warning will be raised and will default to 'Calculated' behaviour.

    Approved

    pControl will retrieve all proposed orders that are in ‘Approved’ state from the investment options and create the ‘Approved’ offsetting trades in the default options.

    Calculated

    pControl will retrieve all proposed orders that are in ‘Calculated’ state from the investment options and create the ‘Calculated’ offsetting trades in the default options.

  • Asset Class for Default Option Offset Trade
    • This attribute defines the entity that a Balancing (Default) Option will place all reversing transactions into during the cash allocation process.

Interdependencies
  • Cash residual rounding tolerance
    • One of the Default Processing Attributes, is also used by this function to indicate tolerance

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Reversing transactions created for all investment options linked to the balancing (default) option and potentially a transaction created into the offset asset class that has been set.

 
[LD050] - Load Liquidity Account Balances

 

Business Description

This function will load the liquidity account balances for use in the later calculations (calculate cash to allocate).

Processing Detail

When selected, the function loads the liquidity account balances from the nominated liquidity account on the entity.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Liquidity Account Balances
    • This attribute references a Liquidity Account entity that defines which internal balances are to be retrieved and summed to generate a liquidity balance for the entity.
  • Cash Accounts
    • The appropriate Liquidity Accounts entity is required to be set on the processing entity in order to load liquidity account balances. Internal balances of each of the pControl accounts listed will be loaded and summed together to generate the liquidity balance. In the example set up below, balances would be loaded as follows:
    Balance of CASH AT BANK, as at Processing Day (T)
    Balance of the APPLICATIONS RECEIVABLE as at T+2
    Balance of the PURCHASES PAYABLE as at T+1
    Balance of the REDEMPTIONS PAYABLE as at T+3

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Calculated liquidity balance (at T and using Days Forward) for the liquidity entity associated with the fund on which cash allocation is being run.

 
[LD060] - Load Forward Liquidity Account Balance Projections

 

Business Description

This function produces a projected liquidity balance for the entity which is displayed in status messages.

Processing Detail

When selected, this function provides a projected liquidity balance using the Cash Accounts information on the Liquidity Accounts entity and a predetermined calendar type.

Note: This value is for information purposes only and is not used in the CAR process.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Liquidity Account Balances
    •  This attribute references a Liquidity Account entity that defines which internal balances are to be retrieved and summed to generate a liquidity balance for the entity.
  • Cash Accounts
    • The liquidity entity stores the list of internal cash accounts to be used in the projection.
    Note: The 'Days Forward' value is not used in the projection calculation.
    The forward looking projection of cash flows is calculated based on the transactions currently approved in pControl. Instead of using the values in the ‘Days Forward’ column, (as per [LD050] - Load Liquidity Balances), this calculation will sum the values in the below accounts for each of the following time periods T+1, T+2, T+3, T+5, T+10, T+20.
  • Cash Allocation Forward Looking Liquidity Calendar
    • This attribute determines which calendar within pControl will be used for forward liquidity calculations for the entity.
  • Use Alternate Calendar Source
    • If the 'Use Alternate Calendar Source' check box is selected, valid working days will be sourced from the L390: Working Days worktable.
  • Alternate Liquidity Calendar Name
    • Where the ‘Use Alternate Calendar Source’ is selected for forward liquidity calculations, the Alternate Liquidity Calendar Name must be populated with the name of the calendar to be used (from the L390: Working Days worktable).

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Calculated Forward Liquidity Balance Projections for the entity are displayed through status messages.

Business Description

Processing Detail

These liquidity adjustments are used to adjust the liquidity balance calculation for an entity on a given date or date range.

Entity Data Attributes Used

    When this attribute is selected and records are present in the U305 worktable, processing continues..

[LD120] - Load COB Liabilities

 

Business Description

This feature applies to UK Life Companies that perform Asset/Liability Matching (ALM).

Some Life Companies do not expect to generate a net new money cash flow for each charging series when performing their cash allocation process. Instead looking from a holistic view of a fund by comparing the total value of the liabilities against the total value of the assets, the difference is the mismatch that the Life Companies will make a dealing decision on. pControl can calculate the total liabilities value by loading the U306: Cash Allocation Liabilities worktable. There are three different type of liabilities that can be loaded into pControl: COB, Intra-day and Manual Adjustment.

Processing Detail

For COB Liabilities, the ‘Units’ or the ‘Value’ can be entered in the U306: Cash Allocation Liabilities worktable to derive the total liabilities value.

  • If ‘Units’ field is used, the Price type field should also be specified so that liabilities can be calculated.
    • $Calculate\ Value\ =\ Units\ \times Price$

    Where price is the last approved price in pControl for the current entity on or before the current effective date for the price type specified in the 'Price Type' field.
  • If ‘Value’ field is used, ‘Units’ field is not required to be populated.
Validation Formula (will fail if)  

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • [LD120] - Load COB Liabilities Mandatory
    • When selected on the process template and the entity and data is present in the U306 worktable, pControl will continue the cash allocation process.
    If there is no data present in the U306 worktable, an exception will be raised.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function.

[LD160] - Look-through ALRs

 

Business Description

Classification look-through provides the ability to look through a plan's investment structure allowing compliance checking of the underlying child assets on the Portfolio Management classification structure panel.

Processing Detail

The classification structure can be populated by:

  • Using externally sourced look-through weights. This is known as External Look-through with data loaded into the U490: External Look-through worktable.
  • Using Investment Allocation Parameters (ALPs) or Investment Allocation Records (ALRs) as the source of weights. This is known as Internal Single Level.
  • Using the Internal Look-through worktable as the source of weights which is considered Internal Multi Level. This uses the P490: Look-through worktable.

The weights and values of the plan's direct assets, (i.e. the investment ALR), are pro-rated by their child asset weights to create a look-through ALR for each child asset. The child assets can be assigned to a look-through classification structure. CAR will then create a classification ALR allowing the child assets to be displayed in a classification and used in compliance checks.

Child assets can be externally sourced holdings or factors, or internal investment structure entities.

Internal Look-through

Data is written to the P490: Internal Look-through worktable as part of the look-through process.

Field name

Entity or Investment ALR source

Plan

The process entity on which CAR is being run, the parent in the look-through relationship. This is used to determine the assets. These assets are then used to determine the child assets.

Effective Date

The process date on which CAR is being run.

Source

P490

Level

Entity attribute indicating which level of data to retrieve from the sources.

Asset

A list of assets from the Investment ALR (T215) for the 'Plan' and the 'Effective Date'.

Child Asset

For each asset a list of child assets from the P490 where:

p490.pControl_code = 'Asset' and

p490.effective_date = 'Effective Date' and

(If 'Level' = lowest then where is_bottom = 0, else where p490.chain_length = 'Level')

Child Weight

For each child asset, the allocation percent from the P490 for the child asset selection.

Note: If there are no records in the P490 worktable for the effective date, the latest date set prior to the effective date will be used and a message displayed accordingly.

 

 External Look-through

The external look-through data is loaded into the U490: External Look-through worktable. Similar to the P490: Internal Look-through worktable, the process for retrieving data from the U490 is the same as for the P490 except instead of calculating the look-through data from the investment path, the U490 may hold investment path and other types of look-through weights such as risk factors or asset class components. Therefore, there is an additional field in U490 for a classification tag.

 

 ALR Look-through

The ALR look-through (T215) refers to using the output of CAR processing from lower level plans, as the weights in the look-through calculation. Although an Investment ALR could be used to go down multiple levels in the investment structure, the ALR look-through can only be used to view one level down. The internal look-through should be used if multiple levels of the investment structure are to be looked through.

Field name

Entity or Investment ALR source

Plan

The process entity on which CAR is being run, the parent in the look-through relationship. This is used to determine the assets. These assets are then used to determine the child assets.

Effective Date

The process date on which CAR is being run.

Source

T215 Investment ALR

Level

N/A

Asset

A list of assets from the Investment ALR (T215) for the 'Plan' and the 'Effective Date'.

Child Asset

For each asset a list of child assets from the T215 where:

t215.plan_entity_node_id = 'Asset' and

t215.effective_date = 'Effective Date' and

where the master status stream has a state of finished

Note: The status stream should be in a state of finished so as not to select from CAR runs where processing is not finished and the proposed orders not approved.

Child Weight

For each child asset, the after weight from the T215 for the child asset selection.

Note: It is expected that Start of Day processing will be run daily and will provide the look-through data as the process is automatically finished and all orders are approved. In cases where there are two or more CAR runs for a day that have been completed, the latest run will be used.

 

 ALP Look-through

The ALP look-through (T210) refers to using the Asset's Investment ALP Target and Strategic weights as the weights in the look-through calculation. The data source will specify either the target or strategic weight. The selection process is the same, except a different column is used for the child weight.

Field name

Entity or Investment ALR source

Plan

The process entity on which CAR is being run, the parent in the look-through relationship. This is used to determine the assets. These assets are then used to determine the child assets.

Effective Date

The process date on which CAR is being run.

Source

T210 Investment ALP

Level

N/A

Asset

A list of assets from the Investment ALP (T210) for the 'Plan' and the 'Effective Date'.

Child Asset

For each asset a list of child assets from the T210 where:

t210.plan_entity_node_id = 'Asset' and

the latest t210.start_date <= 'Effective Date' and

Note: when selecting from the t210 Allocation Parameter table, the start date may be ragged i.e. not all assets will have the same start date. The process needs to select the latest start date on or prior to the effective date for each asset.

Child Weight

For each child asset, the target or strategic weight from the T210, depending on the data source selected.

 

 Consistency check

The Investment ALR will be pro-rated to create Look-through ALR.

Using the data selected from one of the sources, there is a Plan and Effective Date:

  1. A list of the Plan's assets.
  2. Multiple lists of Child Assets (one for each of the Plan's Assets).
  3. A child weight for each child asset.

A Look-through ALR is created for each child asset, which is based on the parent, but with changes that are outlined below.

Note: For each asset, the sum of child weights must equal 100%. If this does not occur, then there is a data inconsistency and an exception will be raised.

ALR creation

Changes required to create a Look-through ALR for each child asset

Changes to record identifiers

asset_id

Replace with the Child Asset ID

counterparty_id

Replace with Child Asset ID

allocation_record_type

Replace with LT ALR record type

originator_id

Replace with asset_id

Note: this is the original asset id, not the updated one.

The following fields are multiplied by the child weight

initial_pre-start_weight

initial_pre_start_inv_bal_base

proposed_order_asset

pre_start_weight

pre_start_inv_bal_base

proposed_ord_base

initial_weight

initial_inv_bal_base

proposed_ord_units

start_weight

start_inv_bal_base

proposed_ord_weight

actual_weight

after_inv_bal_base

actual_ord_asset

after_weight

initial_inv_bal_asset

actual_ord_base

actual_after_weight

start_inv_bal_asset

actual_ord_units

after_inv_bal_asset

after_units

 

Fields populated with new values

rel_id

last_updated_date

 

last_updated_by

integrity_version

 

Fields populated with the same value

effective_date

price_run_type_id

external_reference

batch_number

price_type_id

is_master

alr_tag

transaction_type__id

order_id

alr_type

plan_entity_node_id

 

 

 Aggregating across like child asset

In the case where the Look-through ALR has the same asset and originator ID, then these are aggregated as there is only one place in the tree to map these child assets.

When multiple instances of the same child asset exist, then:

  1. The value and weights fields are summed.
  2. The new value fields are to take new values.
  3. The following same value fields are not to be populated: external_reference, order_id, and transaction_type_id.

 

 Example - Internal Look-through using the P490

Internal Look-through using the P490

In this example, the look-through source has been set to internal at the lowest level.

ALR Data

Plan: ABC has three assets: Asset A, Asset B and Asset C with weights of these assets within ABC of: 20%, 30% and 50% respectively. The CAR process results are as follows:

Plan

Effective Date

Asset

After Weight

Data Source

Data source options include Allocation records, External, Internal, Strategic allocation parameters or Target allocation parameters.

When the Allocation Records, Target Weights, or Strategic Weights option is chosen as the data source, then the chain length level / look through level can only be one.

If a deeper look-through level is required, then the look-through process should be run at a deeper level with the internal data source.

Chain length level

The chain length level refers to the number of levels to look through down from the asset for the internal and external look-through.

ALP Allocation type

Standard – ‘Standard’ allocation parameters are used when defining a target investment structure which is not dependent on the net cashflow movement on the processing day.

Ad-hoc – ‘Ad-hoc’ allocation parameters are used when defining a target investment structure for the purposes of Ad-hoc rebalancing.

Application – defines the target investment structure for an entity which has a positive liquidity balance on the given processing day i.e. due to receiving net application cashflows

Redemption – defines the target investment structure for an entity which has a negative liquidity balance on the given processing day i.e. due to receiving net redemption cashflows.

Pre Calculation Validations

This processing phase validates any data that has been loaded to ensure it is appropriate for cash allocation processing to continue.

[VD010] - Check Allocation Parameters Sum to 100%

 

Business Description

This function checks that the set of Allocations Parameters (ALPs) that have been loaded for an entity sum to 100%.

Processing Detail

When selected, the ALPs are summed to 100% and where true processing will continue.

The CAR process will stop and an exception will be raised in any of the following circumstances:

  • There are no ALPs loaded for the fund
  • There are Application, Redemption AND Standard Allocation Types loaded for the fund (there should either be Standard types OR Application and Redemption types)
  • The sum of Standard Allocation Type ALPs for the Fund does not sum to 100%
  • The sum of Application Allocation Type ALPs for the Fund does not sum to 100%
  • The sum of Redemption Allocation Type ALPs for the Fund does not sum to 100%
  • There is an Application Allocation Type ALP with no corresponding Redemption Allocation Type ALP, i.e. an application allocation type ALP into an asset with no corresponding redemption allocation type ALP into the same asset.
  • There is no ALP into the associated Liquidity Entity.
Validation Formula (will fail if)

An exception will also be raised on the master proposed order, users can have the following options will be available for transition:

  • Run in Error – to cancel the cash allocation process.

[VD030] - Check Units on Issue

 

Business Description

This function checks the pControl internal units on issue against the units on issue in the U108: Units on Issue worktable.

Processing Detail

Where the pControl internal confirmed units are less than the unit threshold value, the validation will not be run as part of the process, the process will continue.

Where the pControl internal confirmed units exceed or equal the unit threshold value, the validation will run as part of the processing and:

  • If data is present in the U108: Units on Issue worktable for the effective date and the unit difference is within the tolerance specified on the entity, processing will continue.
  • If data is present in the U108: Units on Issue worktable for the effective date, but the unit difference is outside of tolerance, an exception will be raised.
  • If there is no data present in the U108: Units on Issue worktable for the effective date, an exception will be raised.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Unit Threshold
    • This validation will only be performed when pControl confirmed units are greater than this threshold value i.e. if pControl Units = 50,000 and unit threshold is 100,000 this validation will not be performed.
  • Unit Difference Tolerance
    • This is the tolerance established for the validation i.e. the validation will breach if the unit difference between the confirmed units and the U108 confirmed units is greater than this tolerance i.e. If pControl confirmed units = 50,000 and U108 confirmed units =50,100 and the unit difference tolerance = 100 the validation will pass. If the unit difference tolerance = 50 the validation will fail.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • [LD020] - Load Investment Holdings

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
[VD040] - Validate COB AU Value vs Liabilities Mismatch

 

Business Description

This feature applies to UK Life Companies that perform Asset/Liability Matching (ALM).

This function checks whether the mismatch value (between COB Liabilities value and AU Value) is within the tolerance amount specified in the ‘Mismatch Tolerance Amount’ in the ‘AU Value vs Liability Mismatch’ attribute.

Processing Detail

The mismatch value is checked against a tolerance specified in the ‘Mismatch Tolerance Amount’.

$Mismatch\ Value\ =\ Total\ COB\ Liabilities\ -\ Total\ AU\ Value$

The COB Liabilities amount is loaded from the U306: Cash Allocation Liabilities worktable either through:

  • Amount populated in 'Value' field, or
  • Amount calculated from 'Units' field multiplies by the last approved price type specified in the U306 worktable.

When this function is selected and the Mismatch Tolerance Amount specified on the entity, the following occurs:

  • If the mismatch amount is within the tolerance amount, processing will continue. 
  • If the mismatch amount is outside the tolerance amount, an exception will be raised.

The AU value is covered in 'Calculation Configuration' phase - Jen to add in bookmark.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • [VD040] - AU Value vs Liability Mismatch
    • The mismatch tolerance amount must be populated when the function is selected on the process template.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • COB Liabilities from the U306: Cash Allocation Liabilities worktable
  • Load investment holdings from 'Asset Unit Entity' and calculate the AU Value

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function and an exception raised where tolerance is breached.

 
[VD060] - Classify Assets

 

Business Description

This function ensures that the asset classification process is run as part of the CAR or Start of Day processes.

Processing Detail

To assist in the maintenance of the Classification Parameters, the default asset classification and a classification check are attributes in the Cash Allocation process template. As the non-leaf nodes of a classification are mainly static and shared across multiple plans, and the leaf nodes for a plan (i.e. the assets) can change on a more regular basis, maintenance of these assets on a per plan basis can be reduced by using the Default Asset Classification functionality.

Sectors that share the same code as the asset are referred to as Default Sectors. Default Asset Classification will automatically assign the asset to their default sector.

There are two attributes in the Cash Allocation Process template to determine asset classification.

  • Classify Assets
    • When selected, this attribute ensures that the asset classification process is run as part of the CAR or Start of Day processes.
  • Check for Unclassified
    • The default sector refers to a sector with the same code as the unclassified asset. pControl will check to see if a matched sector exists and is of type H - holding. If there is no match found an exception is raised.

Pre Calculations

[PRC010] - Crossing Algorithm

 

Business Description

Crossing is an interfund, asset-level process that attempts to move positions across all funds participating closer to target, without placing trades in the market. Positions are adjusted between/among portfolios of the same level (i.e. in the case of multi-level fund structures) by transferring holdings between originators at NAV price. This is undertaken prior to rebalancing (which is the intra-fund calculation) as a means of reducing transaction costs.

Processing Requirements

Crossing is activated on the CAR process template of the parent (originator) entity, under Rebalancing > Pre-Calculations tab. As this is an asset level calculation that runs across multiple funds in a product group (as a pre-calculation to rebalancing), the rebalancing process for the group must be initiated via bulk submit. The product (crossing) group gets defined on the originator entities via the attribute ‘Crossing Group’.

Crossing is intended to bring assets that are outside tolerances back within tolerance by looking for trading opportunities across the fund structure and within the same level. The crossing process is triggered if any of the holdings within any of the portfolios are outside of tolerance. Where assets have not been able to be brought back fully to target initially, the process then looks to address assets that are in breach. For example, an overweight asset position on one fund can be moved to an underweight position for the same asset in another fund. No orders are placed to the market and all transfers of value occur at NAV price.

The offsetting 'trade' for the crossing is always either the liquidity entity or designated cash entity, as defined on the processing entity. The Crossing Cash entity is not a mandatory attribute (as the processing entity can offset the trades against liquidity).

Entity Data Attributes Used

The following attributes are required to be defined on the entity:

Interdependencies
  • The Crossing process cannot be run on its own; it must be initiated as part of the Rebalancing process.
Prerequisite Functions
  • nil
Outputs
  • The calculated values and results of the Crossing process are exported to the P550: Crossing Calculations worktable.

 

Calculations

The ‘Calculation’ processing phase perform a number of calculations to generate a set of proposed orders for an entity.

[CAL080] - Calculate AU Value vs Liabilities Mismatch

 

Business Description

This feature applies to UK Life Companies that perform Asset/Liability Matching (ALM). This function calculates the total mismatch value between AU Value and Liabilities.

Processing Detail

When this function is selected, pControl will calculate the mismatch value between AU value and Liabilities including liquidity accounts as part of the proposed orders calculation.

$Mismatch\ Value\ =\ Total\ Liabilities\ -\ Total\ AU\ Value\ +\ Liquidity\ Accounts$

where

$Total\ Liabilities\ =\ COB\ + Intra-day\ +\ Manual\ Adjustment$

When the mismatch value is > 0, pControl will generate an Application proposed order.

When the mismatch value is < 0. pControl will generate a Redemption proposed order.

At the end of the cash allocation process, pControl will create an AU Registry order based on total value of the proposed orders that are in an Approved state. Any rejected proposed orders will not form part of the AU Internal Provider order. If tolerances are set on allocation parameters of the investing funds/assets (i.e. Minimum/Maximum/Rounding Amount or Minimum/Maximum/Rounding Units), pControl will adjust the value of the mismatch order (the AU Internal Provider orders) by these breaches in the proposed orders.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Price Type for Valuations
    • The price type from the last approved price of the current entity on or before the current effective date
  • Asset Unit Entity
    • Units = Registered Holders Total Units for the originator specified on the ‘Asset Unit Entity’ attribute.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • [LD120] - Load COB Liabilities
  • [LD130] - Load Intra-day Liabilities
  • [LD140] - Load Manual Adjustment Liabilities
  • [LD020] - Load Investment Holdings (from the Asset Unit Entity)

Outputs
  • AU Registry Orders

 
[CAL040] - Calculate Proposed Orders

 

Business Description

This function calculates the proposed orders for the entity based on the information already loaded and calculated in pControl. The calculation is executed differently depending on the ‘Allocation Methodology’ selected on the entity. The methodologies in pControl are:

Cash Allocation methodologies:

  • Straight Percentage methodology
  • Zero Cash to Allocate methodology
  • Towards Target methodology
  • Box Management methodology

Rebalancing methodologies:

  • Rebalance to Target methodology
  • Partial Rebalance to Percent Target methodology

Processing Detail

Based on the allocation methodology, the ‘Ideal Order’ will be calculated either in cash or unit base for each investment and tested against the criteria set on the relevant allocation parameter.

Prior to the creation of the proposed orders, a validation is performed to ensure:

  • There is a latest approved price available and
  • The price type configured on the fund should match with the price type on the asset’s latest approved price for any assets that the fund is investing in.

If there is no latest approved price, zero price or no matched price type available, an error status message will be displayed.

The following tests are performed on the ‘Ideal Order’ once it has been converted to the currency of the asset (if this is different to the base currency of the fund):

Cash-based Tests Description

Transaction Rounding Amount

If a rounding value has been configured on the ALP, the proposed order will be rounded to the nearest multiple of this value (applications are rounded down towards 0 and redemptions are rounded up towards 0). The resulting rounded order amount is written into the ‘Rounded Order’ field on the proposed order and if the order has been rounded, the rounded order flag will be selected on the proposed order.

Transaction Minimum Amount

If this has been set on the ALP, then the ‘Rounded Order’ will be tested against it and if the rounded order is less than the minimum amount, the ‘Proposed Order’ field will be set to 0 and the ‘Min/Max Breach’ flag will be selected on the proposed order record.

Transaction Maximum Amount

If this has been set on the ALP, then the ‘Rounded Order’ will be tested against it and if the rounded order is greater than the maximum amount, the ‘Proposed Order’ field will be set to the maximum amount and the ‘Min/Max Breach’ flag will be selected on the proposed order.

Unit-based Tests

Description

Transaction Units Rounding

 If a rounding unit value has been configured on the ALP, the proposed order will be rounded to the nearest multiple of this unit value (applications are rounded down towards 0 and redemptions are rounded up towards 0). The resulting rounded order is written into the ‘Rounded Order’ field on the proposed order and if the order has been rounded, the rounded order flag will be selected on the proposed order.

Transaction Minimum Units

 If this has been set on the ALP, then the ‘Rounded Order’ will be tested against it and if the rounded order is less than the minimum units, the ‘Proposed Order’ field will be set to 0 and the ‘Min/Max Breach’ flag will be selected on the proposed order record.

Transaction Maximum Units

 If this has been set on the ALP, then the ‘Rounded Order’ will be tested against it and if the rounded order is greater than the maximum units, the ‘Proposed Order’ field will be set to the maximum units and the ‘Min/Max Breach’ flag will be selected on the proposed order.

The Proposed Order field on the proposed order is updated to the amount that is the result of these tests.

The 'Transaction Type' is set on the proposed order to be:

  • Application Transaction Type if the proposed order amount > 0
  • Redemption Transaction Type if the proposed order amount < 0

The appropriate flags will be selected on the Proposed Transactions panel of the Portfolio Management dashboard:

  • Is Unit Based - the proposed orders are unit base orders
  • Min/Max Breach - the proposed orders have breached the minimum or maximum transaction amount/unit
  • Order Rounded - the rounding tests have been applied to the proposed orders
  • Full Redemption - the proposed orders have breached the 'Cannot have short positions' on the entity attribute
  • Cash Reallocated - the proposed orders have spare cash and 'Reallocate Spare Cash' has been selected on the process template.

Entity Data Attributes Used

The following attributes are used by all cash allocation methodologies (unless otherwise specified):

  • Allocation Methodology
    • Select methodology.
  • Allocation Grouping
    • The setting of this attribute will have an impact on the price date on the proposed order and subsequent actual order. This applies to both cash allocation and rebalancing runs.

    Effective Date

    The effective date allocation grouping will create orders from the fund with a price date equal to the effective date. This is the same as normal cash allocation, i.e. no deferral of cash allocation orders is required.

    Forward

    The forward allocation grouping will create orders from the fund with a price date equal to the greatest deferral (notice) date on the bottom-most-level asset invested in. The settlement date on the proposed order will equal to the ‘Value Date’ configured on the asset entity level.

    Historic

    The historic allocation grouping will create orders from the fund with a price date equal to the last approved price date of the asset. This is similar to standard cash allocation, i.e. no deferral of cash allocation orders is required, although an historic price may be used if historic allocation grouping is specified.

    Forward and Historic

    If ‘Forward and Historic’ allocation grouping is selected, then two cashflows groups from the fund will be created – one containing orders with a forward (deferred price) date, and another with a historic (last approved price) date.

    Orders Criteria

    The ‘Orders Criteria’ allocation grouping uses the allocation criteria in the Orders Criteria attribute table to determine how the incoming cashflows are processed. This ensures that the relevant price date, transaction type or price type for any cashflows received is applied consistently throughout the investment structure.

    Blank

    If left blank, pControl will default to 'Effective Date'.

  • Straight Percentage Weight Method
    •   Determines whether the Target or Current weight from the ALPs is used in the allocation calculations.

    Target Weight

    pControl will use the value set in ALP

    Current Weight

    pControl will use the Asset Allocation

    Blank

    pControl will default to use Target Weight.

    Note: This attribute is only applicable for 'Straight Percentage' methodology.

  • Exclude Unapproved Orders
    • If selected, orders which are ‘Unapproved’ will not be included in the ‘Cash to Allocate’ calculation i.e. where registry orders are not configured to be created in ‘Approved’ state and have not been manually transitioned to ‘Approved’.
    See configuration required to create registry orders in an approved state - Default Processing Attributes - Jen still to add section
  • Rounding Method
    • This rounding method attribute is used in conjunction with the ‘Rounding Amount’ or ‘Units Rounding’ configured on the allocation parameters to determine how the proposed orders are created.

    Round Down

    The negative amounts (typically redemption) are rounded to the nearest multiple of the rounding amount that is FURTHER from zero.

    The positive amounts (typically application) are rounded to the nearest multiple of the rounding amount that is CLOSER to zero.

    Round Nearest

    Both positive (typically application) and negative (typically redemption) amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of the rounding amount.

    Round Towards Zero

    Both positive (typically application) and negative (typically redemption) amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of the rounding amount that is CLOSER to zero.

    Round Using Rules

    Will use client rounding rules.

  • Spare Cash
    • This determines how the residual cash should be allocated. If no option is selected, pControl will default to ‘Largest Investment Holdings (ALP)’.
    For further info refer to Reallocate spare cash - jen to add link once content is added.
  • Cannot Have Short Positions
    • Where a redemption transaction would generate a sale of an underlying asset which is greater than the position held i.e. generate a short position, the selection of this attribute will only allow a ‘full redemption’ transaction to be generated i.e. the full ‘confirmed’ holding will be redeemed and the order marked as a ‘full redemption’. The remaining redemption (which cannot be funded) is reflected as negative ‘Spare Cash’ balance to be funded through future cash allocation processing.
  • Application Transaction Type
    • This determines which transaction type will be used for the ‘Proposed Order’ where the calculated value is > 0.
  • Redemption Transaction Type
    • This determines which transaction type will be used for the ‘Proposed Order’ where the calculated value is < 0.
  • Application Price Type
    • The price type that will be used to calculate the unit value of applications for the proposed order into the underlying asset e.g. NAV Price.
  • Redemption Price Type
    • The price type that will be used to calculate the unit value of redemptions for the proposed order into the underlying asset e.g. NAV Price.
  • Application Dealing Basis
    • This determines whether cash or units will be used to process applications.
  • Redemption Dealing Basis
    • This determines whether cash or units will be used to process redemptions.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions

The following functions are optional pre-requisites but will impact the proposed orders calculated by this function:

  • [LD020] - Load Investment Holdings
  • Calculate Liquidity Balance (Cash to Allocate)
  • [LD030] - Load Calculated and Approved Proposed orders from Investors (for Box Management only)
  • Load All Orders and Calculated Proposed Orders

Outputs
  • Proposed Orders

 
[CAL050] - Reallocate Spare Cash

 

Business Description

The ‘Calculate Proposed Order’ function (as shown above) calculates the ‘Ideal Orders’ that should be made into investments and then performs a number of tests on these ideal orders to generate a set of proposed orders, e.g., minimum transaction test and rounding.

Processing Detail

If an ideal order is rounded or fails one of the tests, the actual proposed order may be different to the ideal and there will be some ‘spare cash’ left over. This spare cash can be a positive or negative figure.

For example:

  • If the ideal order was an application for $550,000 but the maximum order into this asset was set to $500,000, the proposed order would be $500,000 and there would be $50,000 spare cash left over that will not be ‘allocated’.
  • If the ideal order was a redemption for $47,000 but the minimum order into this asset was set to $50,000, the proposed order would be $0 and there would be $47,000 spare cash left over that will not be ‘allocated’
  • If the ideal order was an application for $47,000 and the rounding was set to $5,000, the proposed order would be $45,000 and there would be $2,000 spare cash left over that will not be ‘allocated’

This function will attempt to ‘reallocate’ the spare cash to the fund’s investments to ensure that the fund is fully invested.

There are four methods in which spare cash may be allocated to its underlying proposed orders depending on the option selected in the attribute on the entity.

Note: If the ‘Straight Percentage (with orders criteria)’ methodology has been used and more than one criteria ‘bucket’ has been processed, spare cash will be reported by criteria and will try to be allocated by criteria group using the following process.

  • The new proposed order amount is then tested again using the minimum, maximum and rounding settings from the ALP
  • If any spare cash can be re-allocated to this investment within the tests that are set, the amount that has been reallocated is reported and the Reallocated Cash flag is set on the Proposed Order
  • If the spare cash remaining is still not zero, the next allocation investment is retrieved and the remaining spare cash is added to the Proposed Order and the tests are performed again.
  • This cycle continues until all of the investments have been processed.
  • Any remaining spare cash at the end of this cycle is reported and will remain as liquidity or cash at hand for the fund until the next cash allocation process is executed.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Spare Cash Method
    • There are four methods in which spare cash may be allocated to its underlying proposed orders.
    Note: if not selected, pControl will default to 'Largest Investment Holdings (ALP)'.

    Allocation Priority

    The ‘Priority’ field on the Allocation Parameters (ALP) is used, with the number 1 being the highest priority setting. pControl will retrieve the investment with the highest priority number and reallocate the spare cash to its proposed order to create a new proposed order amount.

    Largest Investment Holding (absolute)

    The spare cash will be reallocated to the largest investment holding, by value. For example, if the current investment holdings value is $100 and $95 respectively, then the spare cash will be allocated to the $100 investment holdings.

    Largest Investment Holding (ALP)

    The target weights are used to determine the priority with which the spare cash should be allocated. All spare cash will go to the investment with the largest target weight. For example, if there is $100 spare cash and there are 3 ALPs for 40%, 40 % and 20%, then the spare cash is allocated to the first highest priority investment, i.e. the one with 40% target weight. If there is more than one investment with the same target weight, the first allocation that is encountered during processing is used.

    Move Closer to Target

    The spare cash will be reallocated to the investment that is furthest away from its target weight (after the initial allocation of cash, not as per starting position). Any spare cash will be allocated up to the investment’s weight, at which point any remaining spare cash would go to the next investment that is now furthest away from its target, and so on.

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Proposed order amended by any spare cash values and spare cash invested.

[POV030] - Import Proposed Orders - Content from Cash Allocation User Guide

 

Business Description

 

Processing Detail

 

Entity Data Attributes Used

[POV040] - Run Compliance Rules

 

Business Description

This function permits the execution of specified compliance rules on all proposed orders before they are approved.

Processing Detail

The rules are executed in the order listed in the table.

If a proposed order fails these checks, an exception is raised.

If a proposed order passes the compliance rules then it is written as a proposed order and;

  • automatically approved if that option has been configured or;
  • will wait to be transitioned to approved by the users

Each compliance rule passes back a true (pass) or false (fail) value and if any of the compliance rules fail, the proposed order will be written with an ‘Exception’ status.

The ‘Processing Notes’ field on the proposed order will record details of the compliance rules that have failed.

There are four courses of action available when faced with a proposed order in an Exception state:

  • Override the Exception
  • Transition the proposed order state to ‘Overridden’, and enter a comment explaining why the compliance rules were overridden. Then transition the proposed order to an ‘Approved’ state which triggers an actual order to be created. The override comments will be displayed in the ‘Processing Notes’ field.
  • Cancel the Proposed Order - transition the proposed order to ‘Pending Cancel’ which cancels the proposed orders with no actual orders created. This is a similar end result to cancelling the process manually. Pending cancel will end the cash allocation process without firing the completion EDNs and therefore will not trigger interfund processes. The cash allocation process can then be re-run at certain level of the interfund.
    • Note: If any of the proposed orders are set to Pending Cancel, all proposed orders will be transitioned to Cancelled, and the Master proposed order is transition to Not Started.
  • Reject the Proposed Order –transition the proposed order to ‘Pending Rejection’ which rejects the proposed orders with no actual orders created however this will mark the cash allocation processed as completed and trigger the next level of cash allocation process to start.
  • Run Again –transition the process to ‘Run Again’ after amending the proposed order (user) amount (via ‘Maintain Proposed Orders’ screen) and re-run compliance rules. This will force the compliance rules to be re-executed and a new result generated which could be another exception if they fail, or an approved proposed order if they pass.

The ‘Comment’ entered by the user is recorded in the process notes field on the proposed order along with the reasons that the compliance rules failed.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Compliance rules

    • Rule Code

    		 Ensure all proposed orders are Approved or Rejected

    This function ensures that all proposed orders are either ‘Approved’ or ‘Rejected’ i.e. treated the same way. This is to ensure that a user does not reject one proposed order and approve another proposed order from within the same cash allocation /rebalance process.

    • If any proposed orders have been transitioned to a state of ‘Pending Rejection’ and there are proposed orders present in a state of ‘Pending Approval’, ‘Override’ of ‘Approved’ or;
    • If any proposeds order have been transitioned to a state of ‘Pending Approval’ or ‘Override’ and there are proposed orders present in a state of ‘Pending Rejection’ or ‘Rejected’;

    All proposed orders will be transitioned to a state of ‘Exception’.

    Note: This compliance rule will be an Entity level compliance rule, i.e. users must select ‘Entity’ in the ‘Apply Rule to’ field.

    Check confirmation date is a valid trade date

    When cash allocation is run, each proposed order calculates an ‘Estimated Confirmation Date’ based on the ‘Start Date’ and ‘Trading Frequency’ attributes configured in the Dealing Details – Subscription / Redemption tab under Order Mgmt of the underlying asset that the entity is invested in.

    When users have been granted the access to override the ‘Estimated Confirmation Date’ in the ‘Confirmation Date’ field on the proposed orders, the ‘Estimated Proceeds Date’ will also be updated accordingly.

    Note: For details regarding override ‘Estimated Confirmation Date’, please refer to Section 5.2.2.2 Maintain Proposed (& Master) Orders.

    This function will validate whether the ‘Confirmation Date’ is a valid trade date based on the configuration in the ‘Start Date’ and ‘Trading Frequency’ attributes.

    • If any proposed order has been transitioned to a state of ‘Pending Approval’ or ‘Override’ and the ‘Confirmation Date’ is not a valid trading date, then the proposed orders will be transitioned to a state of ‘Exception’. pControl will display an ‘Exception’ status with ‘Confirmation Date is not a valid business day’ message.
    • If any proposed order has been transitioned to a state of ‘Pending Approval’ or ‘Override’ and the ‘Confirmation Date’ is a valid trading date, then the proposed orders will be transitioned to a state of ‘Approved’. pControl will display an OK status with ‘Completed Compliance Rules’ message and the process will continue.

    Note: This compliance rule will be a Proposed Order level compliance rule, i.e. users must select ‘Proposed Order’ in the ‘Apply Rule to’ field.

    Check if any external assets have missed cut off

    This function checks if any external assets the entity may potentially invest in down the allocation structure have missed their cut-off time for the effective date of the process. The external entity attribute used for cut off time is referred to the ‘Notice Period Cut-Off time’ on Order Mgmt tab under ‘Dealing Details – Subscription / Redemption’. Please refer to section 4.2.3 Specific Cash Allocation/ Rebalancing Attributes for further details.

    When the proposed orders have been created, pControl will check the current time against the cut-off time configured in the ‘Notice Period Cut-Off time’ attribute

    • If the current processing time > notice period cut-off time on any external entities, the proposed order has missed the cut-off time. pControl will display an ‘Exception’ status with ‘Failed External Asset Cut-off Check’ message and the offending proposed order will have an ‘Exception’ state.
    • If the current processing time < notice period cut-off time on any external entities, the proposed orders have not missed the cut-off time. pControl will display an OK status with ‘Completed Compliance Rules’ message and process will continue.

    Note: This compliance rule will be an entity level compliance rule, i.e. users must select ‘Entity’ in the ‘Apply Rule to’ field.

    Check interfunding trading

    This function checks whether the asset on each proposed order, will ultimately invest into an external product that has been marked as being in a ‘special event’.

    The positive liquidity allocation parameters are used to determine which type of assets the entity would invest into.

    Special events include:

    • ‘Inactive’
    • ‘In liquidation’
    • ‘Closed to new investment’

    If any of the above are true, an exception will be raised on the proposed order. The exception will need to be overridden to allow the process to continue for the entity.

    If the entity will ultimately invest into external products with any of the following special events selected on the external product entities, an exception will be raised on the proposed orders.

    • 'Inactive'
      •  If the entity active check box is deselected, this indicates the external product entity is inactive and therefore no trading will be allowed. The proposed order will be transitioned to 'Exception' state.
    • ‘In liquidation’
      • If selected, the external product entity is considered to be in liquidation and therefore will not accept any purchase orders (transactions). The proposed order will be transitioned to ‘Exception’ state.
    • ‘Closed to new investment’
      • If selected, the external product entity will not accept any orders created from the new investors as there is no existing holding. The proposed order will be transitioned to ‘Exception’ state.  

      Note: The interfund trading compliance rules above can be applied either to Entity or Proposed Order, i.e. users can select either ‘Entity’ or ‘Proposed Order’ in the ‘Apply Rule to’ field.
         Check for Significant Cashflow

    This function checks proposed orders for significant cashflows as a percentage of the asset's NAV and an exception is raised where a defined tolerance is breached.

    The [AP020] - Significant Cashflow function on the entity defines the Significant Cashflow Tolerance (%) and the Asset NAV Value source.

    External

    Loaded from the U070: External NAV worktable

    pControl

    Loads the Total Value of the asset using pControl interfund structures

    Both

    The sum of the two values above to form the total NAV

    The check will fail and an exception raised where:

    $\large \frac{Cash\ Amount\ of\ Proposed\ Order}{NAV\ Amount} \normalsize > Tolerance$

     

    Comment

    This is a free text field, the comment populated will appear in the Value field of the processing status.

    Apply Rule to

    Entity - selected when compliance rules are related to entity attributes

    Proposed Order - selected when compliance rules apply to the actual proposed orders.
     

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • Calculate Proposed Orders

Outputs
  • Proposed Orders validated for special events.

 

Approval

The Approval processing phase contains functions that are used to approve and finalise CAR on an entity.

[PAP030] - Accept / Reject Refactored Tolerances and Bounds

 

Business Description

When an asset is refactored, its tolerances and bounds can be adjusted by the same proportions using the 'Accept/Reject Refactored Tolerances and Bounds' function.

Processing Detail

When this function is selected on the process template, the cash allocation process will create a wait event and a decision must be taken to accept or reject the refactored tolerances and bounds.

  • If the proposed tolerances and bounds are accepted, the proposed orders will be generated using the refactored target weight, tolerances and bounds. There will be no future prompts to accept or reject as long as the attribute is selected.
  • If the proposed tolerances and bounds are rejected, however the proposed orders will be generated using the refactored target weight, and the original tolerances and bounds. On subsequent cash allocation processes, the message will reappear.

If the function is not selected, the orders will be generated using the refactored target weight and the original tolerances and bounds. No warning or prompt will be displayed.

For example, MG Plan holds 4 assets, each with a target weight of 25% and tolerances and bounds as shown in the table below.

If Asset 1 is excluded, the refactored target weights of the remaining assets are 33%. Accepting to refactor the tolerances and bounds will result in the following changes:

Exports

This processing phase contains a number of functions that are used to export data that has been used or calculated by the CAR process to the standard pControl export worktables. This data can then be used for analysis and reporting or exporting to external systems.

[EX030] - Export Cash Allocation Proposed Orders

 

Business Description

When selected, the proposed orders are written to the U580: Cash Allocation Proposed Orders Export worktable.

Processing Detail

Export occurs once the CAR process has been run to a state defined in the multi-select attribute 'Proposed Orders State for Export' (shown below). The records exported to this worktable can report all available ALR fields.

Note: Where multiple states are selected for export (i.e. calculated and approved), the records from previous states are not overridden or cleared out of the worktable.

Entity Data Attributes Used
  • Proposed Order States for Export

Interdependencies
  • nil

Prerequisite Functions
  • nil

Outputs
  • Process status messages report the status of this function

 
[EX040] - Export Projected Proposed Orders

 

Business Description

This function writes the projected proposed orders to the U581: Projected Proposed Orders Export worktable.

Processing Detail

Upon completion of either the Cash Allocation Projection or Rebalancing Projection process, the proposed orders are written to the U581: Projected Proposed Orders Export worktable.
